Extensive Discourses
In ancient times, there were those who possessed only a helmet and a rolled-up collar, yet ruled the world.
Their virtue was one of nurturing without killing,
giving without taking away,
and the world did not criticize their attire,
but embraced their virtue with one heart.
At that time,
the yin and yang were in harmony,
the wind and rain came in their proper seasons,
and all things flourished.
The nests of crows and magpies could be reached down and examined,
and birds and beasts could be tethered and follow along.
Why was it necessary to have elaborate robes and wide belts,
curved lapels and trailing ceremonial caps?
In ancient times, the people lived in damp caves and hollows,
unable to withstand the frost, snow, mist, and dew in winter,
nor the heat, mosquitos, and gadflies in summer.
The sages then built up earth and constructed wood,
creating houses and dwellings,
with upper beams and lower eaves,
to shelter them from the wind and rain,
and to protect them from the cold and heat,
and the people lived in peace.
When Boyu first made clothing,
he spun hemp fibers into threads,
hanging them by hand, thread by thread,
Its completion was like a net.
Later generations made looms to enhance (滕椱) and facilitate its use,
and the people were able to conceal themselves and protect themselves from the cold.
In ancient times, they sharpened the plowshare and tilled the land,
ground clam shells to make hoes,
used wooden hooks for gathering firewood,
and held earthen pots to draw water,
the people toiled hard but gained little benefit.
Later generations made plows, hoes, and rakes,
axes and handles for gathering firewood,
and levered well sweeps for drawing water,
the people were at ease and gained much benefit.
In ancient times, great rivers and famous valleys
blocked and severed roads,
preventing communication,
so they made hollowed logs and square planks
to make boats and rafts,
therefore, whether land was abundant or barren,
they were able to exchange goods.
Traveling thousands of miles on leather shoes required
the hardship of carrying loads on shoulders,
so they made curved wheels and built carriages,
harnessing horses and yoking oxen,
enabling the people to travel far without hardship.
They were harmed by birds of prey and fierce beasts but had no means to defend themselves,
so they made cast bronze and forged iron
to make weapons,
and fierce beasts could no longer cause harm.
Therefore, when the people are pressured by their difficulties, they seek convenience;
when troubled by their worries, they create provisions.
Each person uses their wisdom
to remove what harms them
and to pursue what benefits them.
Constant customs cannot be followed,
tools and instruments cannot be relied upon;
The institutions of antiquity:
at wedding ceremonies, the host was not addressed;
Shun married without informing (his parents);
these were not according to ritual.
Establishing the eldest son as heir:
King Wen abandoned Bo Yikao and used King Wu;
this was not according to established practice.
Ritual dictates marrying at thirty;
King Wen begat King Wu at fifteen;
this was not according to law.
The Xiahou clan encoffined the corpse above the eastern steps;
the Yin people encoffined between the two pillars;
the Zhou people encoffined above the western steps;
these are differences in ritual.
The Yu clan used earthenware coffins;
the Xiahou clan used an earthen enclosure;
the Yin people used an outer coffin;
the Zhou people placed decorated screens on the walls;
these are differences in burial.
The Xiahou clan sacrificed in the dark;
the Yin people sacrificed in the sunlight;
The Three Kings had different affairs, yet their names were passed down to later generations.
All of this is because they adapted to the times and created rites and music.
It is like the way Shi Kuang adjusted the pegs of the zither:
the extent to which they are moved up or down may not be measured in inches or feet,
yet every note is perfect.
Therefore, those who understand the essence of rites and music can create them.
Their words have a fundamental principle within,
and they use it to know the scope of what is proper and correct.
Duke Zhao of Lu had a loving mother and cherished her.
When she died, he wore a linen cap for her,
hence there was the mourning garb for a loving mother.
The Marquis of Yang killed the Marquis of Liao and stole his wife;
therefore, in the great banquet, the rites for the lord's wife were abandoned.
The regulations of the former kings,
if unsuitable, were discarded;
the affairs of later generations,
Good things should be made evident.
Therefore, rites and music have never been constant.
Political teachings have principles,
but effective implementation is paramount.
If it benefits the people,
there is no need to imitate the ancients.
If it is thorough for the matter at hand,
there is no need to adhere to the old ways.
The decline of the Xia and Shang dynasties
was due to their failure to change their laws, which led to their demise.
The rise of the Three Dynasties
was due to their not simply copying each other, which led to their kingship.
Therefore, the sage's laws change with the times,
and rites change with customs.
Clothing and tools are each adapted to their use,
Therefore, changing the ancient ways is not necessarily wrong,
and following customs is not necessarily commendable.
Hundreds of rivers have different sources, but all flow into the sea;
hundreds of schools of thought have different professions, but all strive for good governance.
When the way of the king was deficient, the *Book of Poetry* was created.
When the Zhou royal house declined, and rites and righteousness were ruined,
the *Spring and Autumn Annals* were created.
The *Book of Poetry* and the *Spring and Autumn Annals* are among the finest of studies.
Yet both were products of declining eras.
Scholars follow them to instruct the world.
How can this compare to the flourishing of the Three Dynasties?
Taking the *Book of Poetry* and the *Spring and Autumn Annals* as the ancient Way and valuing them,
there was even a time before the *Book of Poetry* and the *Spring and Autumn Annals* were composed.
To speak of the Way in its incompleteness
is not as good as speaking of the Way in its entirety.
Reciting the *Poetry* and *Documents* of the former kings
is not as good as hearing their words.
Hearing their words
is not as good as grasping the reason for their words.
Grasping the reason for their words
means that words cannot fully express it.
Therefore, the Way that can be spoken of
is not the constant Way.
When the Duke of Zhou served King Wen,
his actions were without self-assertion,
his affairs were not determined by himself,
his body seemed unable to bear the weight of his clothes,
his words seemed unwilling to leave his mouth.
He reverently attended to King Wen,
meticulously and earnestly,
as if incapable of the task,
fearing to lose it.
He can be called a capable son.
When King Wu died,
King Cheng was young and inexperienced.
The Duke of Zhou continued King Wen's work,
occupied the position of the Son of Heaven,
listened to the government of all under heaven,
quelled the rebellions of the Yi and Di barbarians,
punished the crimes of Guan and Cai,
faced the screen and held court with the feudal lords,
determining punishments and rewards,
making decisions without consultation.
His power moved heaven and earth,
his reputation frightened the world within the seas.
He can be said to have been capable in military matters.
Once King Cheng was grown,
the Duke of Zhou relinquished his position and returned the government,
faced north, submitting himself and serving him as a minister,
asking for permission before acting,
reporting back before proceeding.
He had no ambition for arbitrary rule,
and no appearance of boasting or pride.
He can be said to have been a capable minister.
Therefore, that one person changes three times
is how he responds to the times.
How much more so when a ruler changes many generations,
a state changes rulers many times,
people use their position,
to gratify their likes and dislikes,
and use their power and influence to satisfy their desires,
yet they want to use a single type of ritual
A fixed law,
should occasionally change according to the times.
That it cannot hit the mean
is also clear.
Therefore, what the sage follows is called the Way (道),
what he does is called affairs (事).
The Way is like metal and stone,
once tuned, it does not change;
affairs are like zithers and lutes,
the tuning is changed at the end of each piece.
Therefore, laws, regulations, and rites
are tools for governance,
but not that by which one governs.
Therefore, taking benevolence as the warp,
and righteousness as the woof,
this is what will not change for ten thousand generations.
As for examining people's talents,
and at times considering their use,
even daily change is permissible.
How can the world have constant laws?
When fitting with world affairs,
obtaining from human principles,
according with Heaven and Earth,
bringing auspiciousness to ghosts and spirits,
then one can have correct governance.
In ancient times, the people were honest and the craftsmen were genuine,
In a simple and unsophisticated society, even young girls
are such that political teachings are easily transformed,
and customs are easily changed.
Now, as virtue declines further,
and customs become increasingly shallow,
to attempt to use the methods for simple and unsophisticated children
to govern people who are already corrupt
is like trying to control a runaway horse without a pointed arrow, a bit for the mouth, or a spur.
In the past,
Shennong had no regulations or commands, yet the people followed,
Tang and Yu had regulations and commands, but no punishments,
the Xiahou clan did not break their word,
the Yin people made oaths,
and the Zhou people formed alliances.
Reaching the present age,
people endure insults and treat disgrace lightly,
are greedy for gain and have little shame.
To try to govern them with the Way of Shennong
will surely lead to chaos.
Bo Chengzigao resigned from being a feudal lord to farm,
and the world praised him.
People of the present time
who resign from office and live in seclusion
are looked down upon by their village,
how can they be compared to him!
Ancient warfare
used only bows and swords,
"cao rou" had no striking actions,
The halberd is altered to be without a point.
The weapons of later times
use scaling ladders to attack,
and siege shields to defend,
repeating crossbows to shoot,
and dismantled carts to fight.
In ancient times, when attacking a state,
they did not kill the young,
nor capture the elderly.
What was considered righteous in ancient times
is now a laughingstock.
What was considered honorable in ancient times
is now considered shameful.
What was considered order in ancient times
is now considered chaos.
Shennong and Fuxi did not use rewards and punishments, yet the people did not do wrong.
However, those who establish government cannot abolish the law to govern the people.
Shun held a shield and axe and subdued the Miao people.
However, those who wage war cannot relinquish armor and weapons to control the strong and violent.
From this, it can be seen that
are for discussing the customs of the people and controlling urgency;
tools and weapons
are made appropriate by adapting to changes in time.
The sage makes laws and all things are regulated by them;
the worthy establish rites, and the unworthy are bound by them.
The people who are restrained by laws
cannot be tasked with distant expeditions.
Those who are bound by rituals
cannot be made to respond to changes.
Those whose ears cannot distinguish between clear and turbid sounds
cannot be entrusted with tuning musical instruments.
Those whose hearts do not understand the source of order and chaos
cannot be entrusted with establishing laws and regulations.
One must possess unique powers of hearing
and unique clarity of vision
to be able to single-handedly grasp the Way and act accordingly.
Indeed, the Yin dynasty changed the Xia,
the Zhou changed the Yin,
the Spring and Autumn period changed the Zhou.
The rituals of the Three Dynasties were different;
which antiquity should we follow?
Great men create, and disciples follow.
If one knows the source from which governance by law arises,
then one can adapt to the times and change accordingly.
If one does not know the source of governance by law,
even if one follows antiquity,
it will ultimately lead to disorder.
The laws and statutes of the present age change with the times,
and rituals and customs change with the mores.
Scholars follow and inherit past practices,
relying on books and adhering to the old ways,
thinking that without this, there can be no good governance.
This is like holding a square handle trying to fit it into a round mortise;
wanting to obtain a proper and secure fit
is difficult.
Now the Confucians and Mohists praise the Three Dynasties, King Wen and King Wu,
but do not practice their teachings.
This is speaking of what they do not practice.
They do not change, even though this is not the era.
This is practicing what is not right.
Praising what is right,
practicing what is not right,
therefore, spending the entire day exhausting their minds is of no benefit to governance,
and straining their bodies and depleting their wisdom does not aid the ruler.
Now, a draftsman likes to draw ghosts and demons,
but hates to draw dogs and horses.
Why?
Ghosts and demons do not appear in every age,
while dogs and horses can be seen daily.
To preserve the endangered and govern the chaotic
cannot be done without wisdom.
However, when the Dao gives priority to praising the ancient,
even a fool has more than enough capacity [to do so].
Therefore, a method that cannot be used,
the sage kings did not practice;
words that cannot be verified,
the sage kings did not listen to.
Of the Qi of Heaven and Earth,
nothing is greater than harmony.
Harmony is when
yin and yang are balanced,
day and night are distinct,
and things are produced.
They are born at the spring equinox,
and completed at the autumn equinox.
This birth and completion
must obtain the essence of harmony.
Therefore, the Way of the Sage is
broad yet dignified,
strict yet warm,
gentle yet upright,
fierce yet benevolent.
Too much rigidity leads to breaking,
too much softness leads to curling.
The Sage resides precisely between rigidity and softness,
and thus attains the root of the Way.
Accumulation of yin leads to sinking,
accumulation of yang leads to flying;
yin and yang connecting
is what achieves harmony.
Now, the cord used as a measuring device
can be rolled up and kept in one's bosom.
When pulled and stretched,
it can be straight and give a true measure.
Therefore, the Sage takes it as a model for his own person.
Being long without being unwieldy,
Short yet not exhausted,
straight yet not rigid,
enduring yet not forgotten—
is this not only the plumb line?
Therefore, extending kindness leads to weakness;
weakness leads to a lack of authority.
Extending severity leads to fierceness;
fierceness leads to a lack of harmony.
Extending love leads to indulgence;
indulgence leads to a lack of order.
Extending punishment leads to cruelty;
cruelty leads to a lack of affection.
In the past,
Duke Jian of Qi relinquished control of his state
and exclusively entrusted it to his ministers.
The generals and ministers seized power and authority,
private factions formed,
and public good was not practiced.
Consequently, Chen Chengchang and Chi Yizipi were able to accomplish their rebellion.
What caused the line of Lü to be cut off and the Chen clan to possess the state
was born of this softness and weakness.
Zheng Ziyang was firm and resolute, and favored punishments;
in his punishments,
he was resolute and unforgiving.
A retainer who broke a bow
feared punishment and execution,
and thus, taking advantage of the commotion caused by a rabid dog, killed Ziyang.
This was the result of being rigid and fierce.
Nowadays, those who do not understand [the proper way],
seeing the meek being encroached upon,
pride themselves on being firm and resolute;
seeing the firm and resolute perish,
pride themselves on being meek and yielding.
This is because they have no inner foundation,
and their perceptions are discordant and erratic externally,
therefore they never have a fixed course in life.
It is like the singing of one who does not understand music;
if it is made deep, it is stifled and lacks modulation;
if it is made high, it is strained and out of tune.
But when it comes to the singing of Han E, Qin Qing, and Xue Tan,
and the songs of Hou Tong and Man Sheng,
filled with purpose,
accumulated internally,
overflowing and expressing itself in sound,
then everything conforms to the musical rules and resonates with people's hearts.
Why is this?
Because they have an inner foundation to determine high and low tones,
not influenced by externals, but self-regulating.
Now, a blind man walking on the road,
if someone tells him to go left, he goes left;
if someone tells him to go right, he goes right;
if he meets a gentleman, he is easily guided to the correct path;
if he meets a petty person, he falls into ditches and gullies.
Why is this?
Because his eyes have no way to perceive things.
Therefore, Wei, using both Lou Zhai and Wu Qi, lost the West of the River;
King Min exclusively employed Nao Chi and died in the Eastern Temple because
he lacked the skill to control him.
King Wen employed both Lü Wang and Shao Gong Shi and became king
King Zhuang of Chu exclusively relied on Sun Shu'ao and became a hegemon,
because he had the skill to control him.
Stringed music, singing, drumming, and dancing are considered pleasure;
circling and bowing are used to cultivate ritual propriety;
lavish burials and prolonged mourning are used to send off the dead.
These are what Confucius established,
yet Mozi criticized them.
Universal love and valuing the worthy,
revering spirits and rejecting fate,
these are what Mozi established,
yet Yang Zhu criticized them.
Preserving one's nature and guarding one's true self,
not allowing external things to burden one's form,
these are what Yang Zhu established,
yet Mencius criticized them.
People's inclinations to accept or reject differ,
and each has their own understanding.
Therefore, right and wrong have their place;
if one finds their place, there is no wrong;
if one loses their place, there is no right.
The people of Danxue, Taimeng, Fanzhong, Kongtong, Daxia, Beihu, Qigong, and Xiugu
have different standards of right and wrong,
and their customs are contradictory.
Yet rulers and ministers, superiors and inferiors,
Husbands and wives, fathers and sons,
have that which they use to employ each other.
What is right here,
is not what is right there;
What is wrong here,
is not what is wrong there;
It is like the axe, adze, mallet, and chisel, each having its specific application.
In the time of Yu,
he used the five musical tones to govern,
hanging bells, drums, chimes, and clappers,
and placing a hand drum,
to await men from the four directions.
He made an announcement saying:
"Those who teach me the Way, strike the drum;
those who instruct me in righteousness, strike the bell;
those who inform me of affairs, shake the clapper;
those who tell me of worries, strike the chime;
those with lawsuits, shake the hand drum."
At that time,
he would rise ten times during a single meal,
and grip his hair three times during a single bath,
to labor for the people of the world.
If, under these circumstances, one could not express virtue and manifest loyalty,
then it was a lack of talent.
In the time of Qin,
they built high terraces and pavilions,
created large parks and gardens,
He extended the roads far and wide for imperial travel,
cast bronze statues,
dispatched those fit for military service,
collected fodder and straw,
imposed head taxes and levied taxes like gathering with a winnowing basket,
and transported it all to the Imperial Treasury.
Able-bodied men,
westward reached Lintao and Didao,
eastward reached Kuaiji and Fushi,
southward reached Yuzhang and Guilin,
northward reached Feihu and Yangyuan;
along the roads, the dead were measured by the ditchful.
At that time,
loyal remonstrators were called inauspicious,
and those who spoke of benevolence and righteousness were deemed mad.
It was not until the Gao Emperor
preserved the dying and continued the extinguished,
raised the great banner of righteousness for all under heaven,
personally rolled up his sleeves and grasped weapons,
to plead for the people's lives before Heaven.
At that time,
heroes and outstanding talents throughout the land were exposed in the wilderness,
facing arrows and stones in front,
and falling into ravines behind,
emerging from a hundred deaths to grasp a single life,
in order to contend for the power of the empire,
rousing their martial spirit and employing their sincerity,
to decide the fate of a single day.
At that time,
those who wore loose robes and wide belts and spoke of Confucianism and Mohism
were considered unworthy.
After violent rebellions had been overcome,
the country was pacified,
he continued the work of civil administration,
established martial achievements,
assumed the position of the Son of Heaven,
created the crown of the Liu family,
unified the Confucians and Mohists of Zou and Lu,
spread the teachings left behind by the former sages,
bore the banner of the Son of Heaven,
rode in the Great Carriage,
erected nine-streamer flags,
struck the great bell,
beat the resounding drum,
performed the "Xianchi" music,
and brandished shields and axes.
At this time,
someone who established martial merit was viewed with suspicion.
Within a single generation,
civil and martial affairs alternately became dominant,
used as the times dictated.
Now, those who engage in martial affairs reject civil affairs,
and those who engage in civil affairs reject martial affairs.
Civil and martial affairs criticize each other,
and they do not understand how the times use them.
This is seeing only one corner of a confined space,
and not know the vastness of the eight extremes.
Therefore, facing east and looking,
one does not see the west wall;
facing south and observing,
one does not behold the north.
Only he who has no particular direction
is able to be unobstructed in all directions.
The reason a state survives
is because of morality (dao and de);
the reason a family perishes
is because of the obstruction of principle.
Yao did not possess a walled city of even a hundred households,
Shun did not possess land to stick in a gimlet;
yet they possessed all under Heaven.
Yu did not have a following of even ten people,
Tang did not have a territory of even seven *li*;
yet they became kings among the feudal lords.
King Wen, residing between Qi and Zhou,
with a territory of no more than a hundred *li*,
and yet established himself as the Son of Heaven,
had the Way of a King.
The flourishing of Xia Jie and Yin Zhou,
where people’s footprints reached,
where boats and carriages traversed,
such that everything became commanderies and counties,
and yet they died by other people’s hands,
and were laughed at by all under Heaven,
It has a form that perishes.
Therefore, the sage observes transformations to perceive their signs.
Virtue has waxing and waning;
the winds of change sprout forth beforehand.
Therefore, those who attain the Way of kingship,
though small, will surely become great;
those whose form is destined to perish,
though successful, will surely fail.
When the Xia dynasty was about to perish,
the Grand Scribe Zhong Gu first fled to the Shang,
and within three years, Jie fell.
When the Yin dynasty was about to be defeated,
the Grand Scribe Xiang Yi first returned to King Wen,
and within a year, Zhou fell.
Therefore, the sage's perception of the traces of existence and demise,
the juncture of success and failure,
is not on the plains of Mingtiao,
on the day of Jiazi.
Now, to say that the strong win based on measuring territory and calculating the population,
and the wealthy profit based on weighing grain and measuring gold,
if this were so,
then among the lords of ten thousand chariots, there would be none who did not become hegemons,
and among the states of a thousand chariots, there would be none who did not perish.
The traces of existence and demise
are so easily known that
foolish men and ignorant women can all discuss them.
Zhao Xiangzi became a hegemon with the city of Jinyang,
while Zhi Bo was captured with the lands of the Three Jin;
King Min lost the great Qi state,
while Tian Dan was successful in Jimo.
Therefore, when a state falls,
even if it is large, it is not reliable;
when the Way is practiced,
even if it is small, it should not be disregarded.
From this perspective,
survival lies in obtaining the Way and not in being large,
while destruction lies in losing the Way and not in being small.
The *Book of Poetry* says:
"Then he looked back to the West,
this is where he settled."
This refers to abandoning Yin and moving to Zhou.
Therefore, the rulers of chaotic states
strive to expand their territory but do not strive for benevolence and righteousness,
strive to elevate their positions but do not strive for morality and virtue.
This is abandoning the means of survival
and creating the means of destruction.
Therefore, Jie was imprisoned in Jiaomen,
yet he could not find fault with his own actions,
but regretted not killing Tang at Xia Tai.
Zhou was confined in Xuan Shi,
yet he did not reflect on his errors,
but regretted not executing King Wen in Youli.
If these two rulers had occupied positions of strength
and cultivated the Way of benevolence and righteousness,
Tang and Wu would have been too busy saving them from their crimes,
what plots would they have dared to consider?
If those above disorder the brightness of the three luminaries (sun, moon, and stars),
and those below lose the hearts of the myriad people,
even if they are lesser than Tang and Wu,
who would not be able to seize it (the throne)?
Now, not examining what lies within oneself,
but instead preparing against it in others,
the world is not just filled with one Tang and Wu,
kill one person,
and there will certainly be someone to succeed them.
Moreover, the reason why Tang and Wu were able to become kings while in a small and weak position
was because they possessed the Dao (the Way);
the reason why Jie and Zhou, while in a strong and powerful position, ultimately had their rule seized
was because they lacked the Dao.
Now, not practicing the way by which people become kings,
but instead increasing what causes oneself to be overthrown,
this is the path to ruin.
When King Wu conquered Yin,
he wanted to build a palace on the Five Elements Mountain.
Duke Zhou said:
"That is not allowed!
The Five Elements Mountain
is inherently a place of strategic passes and obstructions.
If our virtue is able to cover it,
then those in the world submitting their tribute will return.
If we have violent and chaotic behavior,
then it will be difficult for the world to attack us."
This is why they were not overthrown for thirty-six generations.
Duke Zhou can be said to have been able to maintain a state of fullness.
In the past,
the *Book of Zhou* had a saying:
"What those above say,
those below implement;
what those below say,
those above implement.
What those above say,
is the norm;
what those below say,
is expediency."
This is the art of survival.
Only a sage is able to understand expediency.
To speak and always be trusted,
to make an appointment and always be on time,
are the highest forms of conduct in the world.
A man named "Straight Body" testified against his father who had stolen a sheep, and Weisheng made an appointment with a woman and died waiting for her.
To be straight and testify against one's father,
to be trustworthy and die for a woman,
although there is integrity and trustworthiness,
who can value these!
To falsely convey orders to the three armies
is a great offense.
Duke Mu of Qin raised troops to attack Zheng,
passing Zhou on his way east.
A merchant from Zheng named Xian Gao was going west to sell cattle
He encountered the Qin army between Zhou and Zheng.
Thereupon, he falsely claimed to be acting on Zheng Bo's orders,
rewarding them with twelve oxen,
treating the Qin army as guests and causing them to retreat,
in order to preserve the Zheng state.
Therefore, in some cases,
sincerity turns into error,
while falsehood turns into merit.
What is meant by disregarding propriety and yet achieving great merit?
Formerly, King Gong of Chu fought with Duke Li of Jin at Yinling.
Lü Qi shot King Gong,
striking his eye and nearly capturing him.
Pan Weng, Yang Youji, Huang Shuaiwei, and Gongsun Bing together plotted to seize him.
King Gong, fearful, lost his composure.
Huang Shuaiwei raised his foot and kicked his body,
whereupon King Gong awoke.
Angered by the lack of respect,
he roused himself and stood up.
The four grand officers then carried him away.
Formerly, Cang Wu Rao married a beautiful wife,
and ceded her to his elder brother.
This is what is meant by loyalty and affection that cannot be practiced.
Therefore, a sage judges the right and wrong of matters,
bending, stretching, bowing, and raising himself in accordance with them.
He has no fixed rules or standards,
sometimes yielding, sometimes extending.
Being weak and yielding like cattails and reeds
is not about being intimidated;
Being firm, strong, fierce, and resolute,
with aspirations soaring like green clouds,
is not boastfulness;
it is to seize the opportune moment and adapt to changing circumstances.
Now, the interaction between ruler and minister,
kneeling and bowing in humility,
is to show respect and ritual;
but when faced with imminent danger,
kicking their body to save them
is something no one in the world can criticize.
Therefore, where loyalty lies,
etiquette is not sufficient to hinder it.
The way a filial son serves his parents,
with a gentle face and humble demeanor,
attending to their clothing and footwear;
but if they are drowning,
then grabbing their hair to save them
is not daring to be arrogant or disrespectful,
but to save them from death.
Therefore, grabbing a father's hair when drowning,
and mentioning the ruler's name during prayer,
are things that cannot be avoided due to the circumstances.
This is where expediency is established.
Therefore, Confucius said:
"One can study together,
but not yet walk the Way together.
One can walk the Way together,
He is not yet ready to be established.
He may be ready to be established,
but not yet ready to be entrusted with authority."
Authority,
is what the sage alone perceives.
Therefore, one who disagrees first but agrees later
is said to know authority;
one who agrees first but disagrees later
is said not to know authority.
One who does not know authority
will turn good into bad.
Therefore, ritual is
the adornment of substance and the ornamentation of artifice.
In situations of sudden urgency and desperate straits,
it is of no use.
Therefore, the sage interacts with the world through formalities,
and engages in what is appropriate with substance,
not clinging to a single path,
becoming stagnant and inflexible.
Therefore, he fails in few endeavors and succeeds in many,
and his commands are carried out throughout the world, and no one can criticize him.
The orangutan knows the past but not the future,
the wild swan knows the future but not the past.
This is the difference in their lengths (of understanding).
Formerly, Chang Hong was the one who maintained the calculations of the Zhou court.
The energy of Heaven and Earth,
the movements of the sun and moon,
The changes of wind and rain,
the calculations of the calendar and musical scales,
he understood everything,
yet he could not understand himself
and died by dismemberment.
Su Qin,
a commoner on foot,
wearing ragged clothes and sandals,
managed emperors of ten thousand chariots,
made the feudal lords submit,
yet could not escape the suffering of being torn apart by chariots.
King Xu Yan wore clothes of kindness and grace,
personally practiced benevolence and righteousness,
thirty-two countries came to his court by land,
yet he died and his country was destroyed,
with no descendants remaining.
The Grand Master Zhong assisted King Goujian of Yue,
and avenged him and wiped away his shame,
capturing the person of King Fucha,
opening up territory for thousands of miles,
yet he died by being forced to commit suicide with the sword Shu Lou.
These men all understood the mechanisms of order and chaos,
but did not understand the means of preserving their nature.
Therefore, Chang Hong knew the way of Heaven but did not understand human affairs,
Su Qin knew strategies and schemes but did not understand fortune and misfortune,
King Xu Yan knew benevolence and righteousness but did not understand the times,
The Grand Master Zhong knew loyalty but did not understand strategy.
Sages are not like this.
They discuss the times and then act accordingly.
They weigh matters and then devise plans accordingly.
Therefore, when they extend their influence throughout the world, it is not excessive.
When they confine themselves to the ordinary, they are not obstructed.
If the world is desolate and chaotic,
ritual and righteousness are severed,
the guiding principles are abandoned,
the strong prey on the weak,
force and conquest are used to encroach upon each other,
ministers and rulers have no distinction,
the noble and the humble have no order,
lice grow on armor,
sparrows nest in tents,
and soldiers do not rest,
and only then do they begin to adopt a submissive appearance
and the rituals of reverence and frugality,
then they will surely be suppressed and unable to rise.
If the world is peaceful and tranquil,
governance and education are harmonious,
the common people are respectful and amicable,
superiors and inferiors are intimate with each other,
and only then do they begin to establish arrogance and
display bravery and strength,
then they will surely not escape the laws of the officials.
Therefore, the sage
is capable of being both hidden and revealed,
capable of being both weak and strong,
Move or be still in accordance with the times,
establish merit based on available resources.
When things move, know their reversal;
when affairs sprout, observe their changes.
When transformation occurs, create images (or models) for it;
when opportunity arises, respond accordingly.
Therefore, one can act throughout life without being trapped.
Thus, there are affairs that are feasible but cannot be spoken of,
there are things that can be spoken of but cannot be done,
there are things easy to start but difficult to complete,
and there are things difficult to complete but easy to ruin.
What is meant by feasible but not to be spoken of is
taking or leaving.
What can be spoken of but cannot be done is
deception and falsehood.
What is easy to begin but difficult to complete is
affairs/projects.
What is difficult to complete but easy to ruin is
governance.
These four strategies are
what the sage uniquely perceives and pays attention to.
To bend an inch to stretch a foot,
the sage does it;
to tolerate a small wrong for a great righteousness,
the virtuous man practices it.
The Duke of Zhou had the burden of killing his brother;
Duke Huan of Qi had the reputation of contending for the state.
However, the Duke of Zhou used righteousness to make up for deficiencies,
and Duke Huan used merit to eliminate ugliness,
and both became worthy.
Now, if we use people's small faults to cover up their great virtues,
then there will be no sage kings or worthy ministers in the world.
Therefore, a flaw in the eye
does not hinder sight,
so it should not be cauterized;
a disease in the throat
does not hinder breathing,
so it should not be drilled into.
The mounds and graves by the river
are too numerous to count,
yet the river is still considered easily fordable.
Water stirs and creates waves,
with high and low parts bordering each other,
differing only by inches and feet,
yet it is still considered level.
Formerly, Cao Zi was a general for Lu,
and lost three battles in a row,
losing a thousand li of territory.
If Cao Zi had not considered the consequences,
and had not turned back,
but had cut his own throat in the midst of battle,
then he would have been a defeated general captured forever.
However, Cao Zi was not ashamed of his defeat,
but was ashamed to die without merit.
At the Covenant of Ke,
To wield a three-foot blade,
and aim for Duke Huan's chest;
what was lost in three battles,
to recover in a single morning;
bravery renowned throughout the world,
merit established in the state of Lu.
Guan Zhong assisted the son Jiu but failed to bring his plans to fruition,
he cannot be called wise;
fleeing and running away,
not dying in his predicament,
he cannot be called courageous;
being bound and shackled,
not shunning the shame,
he cannot be called upright.
Considering these three behaviors,
commoners would not befriend him,
rulers would not employ him as a minister.
However, Guan Zhong was freed from his bonds,
established the government of the state of Qi,
united the feudal lords nine times,
and rectified the entire world.
Had Guan Zhong been willing to sacrifice his life and body,
without regard for future plans,
how could he have achieved such hegemonic accomplishments!
Now, when rulers evaluate their ministers,
they do not consider their great achievements,
but instead scrutinize their minor actions,
and seek out their small virtues,
then they lose the way to find worthy men.
Therefore, if a man possesses great virtue,
do not question his minor faults;
and if he has great renown,
do not find fault with his small mistakes.
Jingyang indulged in wine,
let his hair down and was served by women,
yet he awed and subdued the various lords.
These four men
all had shortcomings,
yet their merit and fame have not been extinguished,
because they grasped the essentials.
Ji Ai and Chen Zhongzi upheld integrity and resisted,
refusing to enter the court of a corrupt ruler,
refusing to eat the food of a chaotic world,
and consequently starved to death.
Why were they unable to preserve existence and continue the interrupted?
Because small principles were emphasized, while the larger strategy was compromised.
Therefore, those who are overly cautious achieve no success,
and those who criticize others are not tolerated by the masses.
Those with a large body have relaxed joints,
and those who stand on tiptoes can reach far.
From ancient times to the present,
the Five Emperors and Three Kings
have never been able to completely perfect their conduct.
Therefore, the *Book of Changes* says:
"Small Fault,
success, furthering through perseverance."
It means that no one is without faults,
but one should not desire them to be great.
Yao, Shun, Tang, and Wu were the most prosperous rulers of their times;
Duke Huan of Qi and Duke Wen of Jin
were the outstanding heroes of the Five Hegemons.
Yet Yao had a reputation for unkindness,
Shun was criticized for his humble parentage,
Tang and Wu had the deeds of banishment and regicide,
and the Five Hegemons had plans for violent rebellion.
Therefore, the gentleman does not demand perfection from one person,
he is upright without being cutting,
honest without being harsh,
broadly knowledgeable without being critical,
and skilled in both civil and military affairs without being demanding.
When seeking something from others, one relies on their abilities;
when cultivating oneself, one relies on morality.
Demanding from others based on their abilities
is easily repaid;
cultivating oneself through morality
is difficult to achieve.
Because it is difficult, conduct is lofty;
because it is easily repaid, one's needs are met.
The jade pendant of the Xiahou clan cannot be without examination,
the pearl of the bright moon cannot be without flaws,
yet the world treasures them.
Why?
Their small flaws are not enough to obstruct their great beauty.
Now, if one focuses on people's shortcomings
and forgets their virtues,
and seeks to find the worthy among the world,
then it will be difficult.
Now, regarding Bailixi feeding oxen,
Yi Yin carrying the cauldron,
Taigong wielding the knife,
and Ning Qi singing as a merchant,
there was something admirable about them.
The multitude sees their lowly positions
and the degrading nature of their tasks, yet they do not understand their grand strategies,
considering them unworthy.
When they become sons of heaven and high ministers,
or are established as feudal lords and worthy prime ministers,
only then do they gain the belief of the masses.
To be discovered from among cooking pots and sacrificial vessels,
to emerge from butcher shops and wine stalls,
to be freed from bondage,
to rise from beneath the chin of an ox,
to be cleansed with hot baths,
to be purified with sacrificial fires,
to be established in the imperial court,
to be relied upon in the positions of the three highest ministers,
to feel no shame before the nation,
and to feel no embarrassment before the feudal lords,
their talents and circumstances must align internally.
Therefore, to know someone's worth before they achieve any merit is like
Yao knowing Shun.
To know someone's worth after they have achieved merit and accomplished deeds is like
the common people knowing Shun.
Therefore, to abandon standards and instead seek people from the court, markets, or among the common grass,
His losses of men must be many.
Why is that?
He is able to imitate the methods of seeking men,
but does not understand the reasons for choosing them.
Things that resemble each other
are what confuse and mislead the rulers of the world.
Suspicious and similar appearances
are what dazzle the masses.
Therefore, the ruthless resemble the wise but are not wise,
the foolish resemble the benevolent but are not benevolent,
and the headstrong resemble the brave but are not brave.
If the difference between men
were like that between jade and stone,
or mallow and amaranth,
then judging men would be easy.
But those who confuse men
are like Ligusticum striatum and Ligusticum jeholense,
or Cnidium monnieri and Sium suave.
Therefore, sword makers are confused by swords that resemble Mo Xie (a famous sword),
only Ou Ye (a famous swordsmith) can name their types;
jade craftsmen are dazzled by jade that resembles blue jade,
only Yi Dun (a famous jade appraiser) does not lose sight of its true nature;
and foolish rulers are confused by treacherous ministers and petty men who resemble virtuous men,
only sages can see the subtle and know the obvious.
Therefore, when a snake raises its head a foot,
its length can be known;
when an elephant shows its tusks,
and greatness and smallness can be discussed.
Xue Zhu, a mediocre man, saw if the fox armor was on the sword, and he knew its sharpness and dullness;
Yu Er and Yi Ya, when the waters of the Zi and Mian rivers combined,
tasted one sip of the water, and knew whether it was sweet or bitter.
Therefore, when a sage discusses the worthy,
seeing one of their actions, the worthy and unworthy are distinguished.
Confucius resigned from Linqiu,
and in the end, he never stole even a knife or hook;
Xu You declined the Son of Heaven,
and in the end, he did not desire to be enfeoffed as a marquis.
Therefore, one who has never been burned but dares not hold fire,
has seen that it burns;
one who has never been injured but dares not hold a knife,
has seen that it hurts.
From this perspective,
seeing something allows one to discuss what has not yet been manifested,
and observing small details is enough to know the big picture.
Therefore, the way to judge a person is:
when they are in a position of honor, observe whom they promote;
when they are wealthy, observe what they give away;
when they are in poverty, observe what they do not accept;
when they are in a low position, observe what they do not do;
when they are destitute, observe what they do not take.
Observe their ability to handle difficulties
to know their courage;
observe their movements with joy and happiness
to observe their steadfastness;
entrust them with goods and wealth
To discuss with them is to understand their benevolence;
to shake them with fear is
to know their integrity;
then the human condition is completely understood.
Those who were good at rewarding in ancient times
spent little and encouraged many;
those who were good at punishing
reduced punishments and prohibited wrongdoing;
those who were good at giving
used frugally and created virtue;
those who were good at taking
received much and without resentment.
Zhao Xiangzi was besieged at Jinyang,
and after lifting the siege, he rewarded five meritorious individuals,
with Gao He being the first to be rewarded.
His attendants said:
"During the difficulty at Jinyang,
He did not have great merit,
yet now he is the first to be rewarded,
why is this?"
Xiangzi said:
"During the siege of Jinyang,
my altars of the soil and grain were in danger,
the state was precarious,
and none of the ministers were without a feeling of arrogance and contempt,
only He did not lose the proper respect between ruler and subject."
Therefore, by rewarding one person,
And those in the world who serve as ministers,
none failed to be ultimately loyal to their ruler.
This is an example of rewarding little but encouraging many.
King Wei of Qi set up a large cauldron in the courtyard,
and enumerated the faults of the magistrate of Wuyan, saying:
"Your praises
reach my ears daily.
Examining your affairs,
the fields are overgrown,
the granaries are empty,
and the prisons are full.
You are deceiving me with wicked deeds."
Thereupon, he boiled him.
Because of this, for thirty-two years Qi had no cases of lost items being unreturned on the roads.
This is an example of economizing on punishments but forbidding wickedness.
Duke Mu of Qin went on an excursion and his chariot broke down,
the right-side horse escaping,
and the country folk obtaining it.
Duke Mu pursued it and caught up with them on the sunny side of Mount Qi,
seeing the country folk were butchering and eating it.
Duke Mu said,
"To eat the meat of a fine horse,
without washing it down with wine,
harms people.
I fear it will injure you all."
He provided wine for everyone and left.
After one year,
in the battle with Duke Hui of Jin at Han,
the Jin army surrounded Duke Mu's chariot.
Liang Youmi seized Duke Mu's chariot horse,
intending to capture him.
The three hundred-plus people who had eaten the horse meat
all came out and fought to the death for Duke Mu beneath the chariot,
and consequently defeated Jin.
Knowing the great from the small.
Therefore, the sage governs broadly by adhering to simplicity.
This is what it means.
Nothing in the world is easier than doing good,
and nothing is more difficult than doing evil.
What is meant by doing good
is being still and without action.
What is meant by doing evil
is being agitated and full of desires.
Satisfying one's feelings and rejecting excesses,
being free from enticement or temptation,
following one's nature and preserving one's integrity,
not changing oneself,
therefore it is said that doing good is easy.
Scaling city walls,
crossing dangerous passes,
forging documents,
stealing seals,
usurping thrones, murdering rulers, falsifying orders,
are not the nature of human beings,
therefore it is said that doing evil is difficult.
Now, the reason people commit crimes leading to imprisonment
and fall into the suffering of punishment and execution
is because their desires are insatiable
and they do not follow due measure.
How do we know this is so?
The laws of the state throughout the land say:
"Those who desecrate graves will be executed,
those who steal will be punished."
This is what the authorities are in charge of.
The laws and decrees are like nets that catch the wicked and evil,
and they closely track their movements.
Even the most foolish men and women
all know that there is no escaping if they commit evil,
and no avoiding punishment if they violate the law.
Yet, worthless sons cannot control their desires,
risk the crime of death,
and suffer the shame of execution and punishment.
After the beginning of autumn,
the officers of the Minister of Justice continually throng at the gates,
and the blood of those executed in the marketplace flows in the streets.
Why is this?
They are deluded by the acquisition of wealth and profit,
and blinded to the calamity of death.
Now, if soldiers are arrayed and troops are set up,
and two armies face each other,
the general issues an order, saying:
"Whoever cuts off an enemy head will be granted a noble title,
but whoever retreats will be beheaded."
Yet, the soldiers under the company leaders are still unable to advance and achieve the merit of cutting off a head,
and instead suffer the crime of being beheaded.
This is abandoning the fear of death to embrace certain death.
Therefore, the reversal of benefit and harm,
the proximity of misfortune and fortune,
must be carefully considered.
Matters that one desires,
often result in one losing them;
matters that one avoids,
often result in one encountering them.
There was a man of Chu who encountered a great wind while riding in a boat.
The waves reached him and he was afraid,
so he threw himself into the water.
It wasn't that he didn't crave life and fear death,
but he was deluded by his fear of death and forgot about living.
Therefore, people's cravings and desires
are just like this.
There was a man of Qi who stole gold.
During the most bustling time of the market,
he reached in, grabbed it, and ran.
When asked the reason for this, he said:
"You stole gold in the middle of the market,
why?"
He replied:
"I didn't see people,
I only saw gold!"
When the will desires something,
one forgets what one is doing.
Therefore, the sage examines the changes of movement and stillness,
and appropriately manages the measure of receiving and giving;
he regulates the emotions of liking and disliking,
and harmonizes the moderation of joy and anger.
If movement and stillness are attained,
Then one worries about not being discovered;
If receiving and giving are appropriate,
then guilt will not accumulate;
If likes and dislikes are governed by reason,
then sorrow will not approach;
If joy and anger are regulated,
then resentment will not intrude.
Therefore, a person who understands the Way
does not seek gain by dishonest means,
and does not steal blessings;
what he possesses, he does not discard;
what is not his, he does not seek;
he is always full but does not overflow,
and constantly empty but easily satisfied.
Now, rainwater is enough to overflow a pot,
but the Yangtze and Yellow Rivers cannot fill a leaky cup.
Therefore, the human heart is like this as well.
One should use the Way and its techniques to measure things,
eat to fill emptiness,
and wear clothes to ward off cold,
then it is enough to nourish the seven-foot form.
If one lacks the Way and its techniques to measure things and practices frugality instead,
then the power of a ten-thousand chariot ruler is not enough to bring honor,
and the wealth of the world is not enough to bring happiness.
Sun Shu'ao thrice relinquished the position of prime minister without showing any worry,
nobility and salary could not burden him;
Jing Ci was surrounded by two dragons coiling around his boat, yet his will did not waver,
Monstrous things should not be surprising.
The heart of a sage is peaceful and his will is easily satisfied.
His spirit is guarded within,
and nothing can delude him.
Consider the drunkard:
Bending down, he enters the city gate,
thinking it to be a seven-foot door.
He leaps across the Yangtze and Huai rivers, thinking them to be ordinary ditches.
Wine has clouded his spirit.
Consider the coward:
At night, seeing a standing pole,
he thinks it is a ghost;
seeing a sleeping rock,
he thinks it is a tiger;
fear has obscured his spirit.
How much more so when it comes to the strange things of heaven and earth!
That male and female join,
that yin and yang interact,
that feathered creatures produce chicks,
that furry creatures produce foals and calves,
that soft things produce skin and flesh,
that hard things produce teeth and horns—
people do not find these strange.
That water produces snails and clams,
that mountains produce gold and jade—
people do not find these strange.
That old locust trees generate fire,
Long-standing blood transforms into will-o'-the-wisp;
people do not find this strange.
Mountains produce owl-like sunbirds;
waters generate water sprites;
trees give rise to firebirds;
wells spawn tomb sheep;
people find these strange.
This is because their hearing and seeing are limited, and their knowledge of things is shallow.
The strange things in the world
are seen solely by sages;
the reversals of benefit and harm
are understood clearly solely by the wise.
Those things that are similar and different, arousing suspicion,
are what delude the common people.
Therefore, seeing cannot be made universal throughout the land,
and hearing cannot be clarified to the common people.
This is why they establish prohibitions based on ghosts, spirits, and omens,
and create changing symbols by generalizing forms and extending categories.
How can we know this is so?
Common sayings go:
"When sacrificing to the great ancestor, a pig is the highest sacrificial animal;
when burying the dead, fur clothing cannot be stored;
when playing with blades, the great ancestor strikes their elbow;
those who sleep with their heads on the door threshold will have their heads trod upon by ghosts and spirits."
All these are not recorded in laws and ordinances,
nor are they transmitted orally by the sages.
Now, that a pig is the highest sacrificial animal when sacrificing to the great ancestor
is not because a pig is more virtuous than wild beasts like deer,
But why do the spirits alone partake of it?
Why is this so?
It is because pigs
are commonly raised by families and are easy to obtain.
Therefore, people take advantage of its convenience to honor [the spirits].
Burying the dead in fur robes that cannot be stored
is not because they can actually provide warmth to the body with fine silk, cotton, and soft cloth.
The world considers fur robes
to be rare and expensive items,
and they can be passed down to later generations.
They are of no benefit to the dead,
but they are sufficient to support the living.
Therefore, people take advantage of their value to intimidate [the living].
When people joke with knives and bump the elbow of the ancestor's tablet,
using knives in jest
will inevitably lead to mistakes.
If mistakes lead to injury,
the harm will certainly be great.
There is no involvement of blood feuds, strife, or fighting,
but involving oneself in punishment and execution over trivial matters
is something that foolish people do not know to avoid.
Therefore, [people] use the ancestor's tablet to burden their minds.
When one sleeps with their head pillowed on the door sill,
it is said that ghosts and spirits will step on their head.
If ghosts and spirits could mysteriously transform,
they would not need doors and windows to travel.
If they go in and out by following empty spaces,
then they would also be unable to step on anything.
Now, doors and windows
are the places where wind and air come and go,
and wind and air
are rough and coarse forces of yin and yang.
Being separated from these will certainly cause illness.
Therefore, [people] rely on ghosts and spirits to express these warnings.
Only Mount Tai;
That which, even in a three-year drought, does not cease flowing,
and whose beneficence extends a hundred li, nourishing grasses and trees,
are only the Jiang (Yangtze) and the He (Yellow) rivers.
Therefore, the Son of Heaven performs the *zhai* sacrifice to them.
Thus, if a horse saves a person from hardship,
when it dies, bury it,
using curtains as its shroud;
if an ox has been virtuous to people,
when it dies, bury it,
using the frame of a large cart as its mat.
If oxen and horses have merit,
it still should not be forgotten,
how much more so for people!
This is why the sages valued kindness and embraced favor.
Thus, when Emperor Yan made fire,
he died and became the hearth;
when Yu labored for the world,
he died and became the altar of the soil;
when Hou Ji created agriculture,
he died and became the altar of millet;
when Yi eliminated harm from the world,
he died and became the Zongbu deity.
This is why spirits and gods are established.
In northern Chu, there was a knight-errant;
his sons and grandsons repeatedly admonished him to stop,
but he did not listen.
In a county, there was a thief.
They thoroughly searched his dwelling.
The matter was indeed discovered.
He was startled in the night and fled.
They pursued him and caught up with him on the road.
Those who had benefited from his kindness all fought on his behalf.
He managed to escape and then returned home.
He said to his son:
"You often tried to stop me from acting as a knight-errant.
Now that I am in trouble,
I have indeed relied on it to save my life.
And you advised me,
which was not to be followed."
He knew how he escaped difficulty,
but he did not know how to avoid difficulty altogether.
To discuss matters like this,
isn't it misguided!
There was a man from the state of Song who was marrying off his daughter.
He told his daughter:
"Marriage may not necessarily succeed.
If you are divorced,
you must secretly hoard wealth.
If you secretly hoard and become rich,
it will be easier for you to remarry."
His daughter listened to her father's plan
and stole and hid things.
The husband discovered that she was a thief
He chased after him and drove him away.
His father did not blame himself,
but instead felt he had gained a good plan.
He knew it was a way to get the wealth out of storage,
but did not understand the reason why the wealth was being released from storage.
To reason like this,
how could it not be preposterous!
Now, consider the renter of carts:
he is trying to salvage the burden of one cart,
and to extend the power of a single ox.
When the axle breaks,
he adds more axles and shafts on top of it to fix the problem,
not understanding that the axle and shaft's purpose is defeated when the axle is already broken.
The King of Chu wore jade pendants while chasing rabbits,
and because he was running, he broke his jade pendant.
He then wore two jade pendants as a precaution,
but the two pendants bumped against each other,
and the breaking became even faster.
The governance of a chaotic state
is similar to this.
The eyes of an owl are large, yet their vision is not as good as a rat's;
the legs of a centipede are numerous, yet it does not run as well as a snake.
Things inherently have cases where the big is not as good as the small,
and the many are not as good as the few.
As for the strong becoming weak,
Weakness turns to strength,
danger turns to safety,
existence turns to extinction.
If not a sage,
who can observe this?
Greatness or smallness, nobility or humility,
are not sufficient for discussion.
Only he who possesses the Dao is valued.
How can this be made clear?
When the Son of Heaven is in the suburban pavilion,
then the nine ministers hasten,
the high officials run,
those sitting prostrate themselves,
those leaning straighten up.
At this time,
in the Bright Hall and the Great Temple,
they hang up their crowns, remove their swords,
loosen their belts, and sleep.
It is not that the suburban pavilion is large and the ancestral temple is small,
but that the most honored one dwells there.
The Dao of Heaven is valued;
it is not merely that the Son of Heaven is honored,
but wherever it is, the multitude look up to it.
Now, hibernating insects and magpie nests
all face the One of Heaven,
for the ultimate harmony lies there.
If the emperor can truly embrace and contain the Dao,
and unite with ultimate harmony,
Then even birds, beasts, plants, and trees would all be covered by its beneficence,
how much more so the myriad people!
"Elucidating Words" states:
Pervading and identical with Heaven and Earth,
chaotic and simple in its essence,
before creation and the formation of things,
it is called the Great One (太一).
Coming forth from the same One,
their actions are each different;
there are birds, there are fish, there are beasts;
this is called the division of things.
Directions distinguish by type,
things divide into groups,
natures and destinies are not the same,
all take form in existence.
Separated and not connected,
divided and becoming myriad differences,
none can return to their source.
Therefore, movement becomes life,
