solemn and silent,
yet bestowing good fortune and receiving blessings.
Therefore, those who obtain the Dao do not falsely beautify themselves,
nor do they falsely pretend to extreme goodness.
One person benefits from it, but it is not lauded;
ten thousand people are covered by it, but it is not confined.
Therefore, valuing the bestowal of favor and valuing the administration of punishment,
then the way to governance will be open.
To bestow favor
is to value generosity.
Without merit yet receiving generous rewards,
without labor yet receiving high rank,
then those who hold office will become lax in their duties,
And those who seek advancement and position are eager to rise quickly.
If one acts violently,
and slaughters indiscriminately,
causing the innocent to die,
and those who act uprightly to be punished,
then those who cultivate themselves will not be encouraged to do good,
and those who do evil will lightly offend their superiors.
Therefore, bestowing favor breeds treachery,
and acting violently breeds chaos.
Customs of treachery and chaos
are the habits of a ruined state.
Therefore, in the governance of an enlightened ruler,
if there is punishment in the state, the ruler does not become angry;
if there are rewards at court, the ruler does not participate.
Those who are punished do not resent the ruler,
because it is what their crime deserves;
those who are rewarded do not feel indebted to their superiors,
because it is the result of their merit.
When the people know that the coming of punishment and reward
all depends on their own actions,
they will focus on achieving merit and cultivating their work,
and will not be dependent on the ruler's gifts.
Therefore, the court is unkempt and without activity,
and the fields are cultivated and without weeds,
so that the supreme ruler
is merely known to exist by those below.
Now, a bridge pillar stands upright and does not move,
He bows and raises his head to take control therein;
the ruler is tranquil and still, not agitated,
and the hundred officials are able to follow the proper path.
It is like the one holding the command flag in the army;
if he points haphazardly, there will be chaos.
Cleverness is not enough to bring great peace,
and intelligence is not enough to secure safety in times of danger.
Rather than praising Yao and denigrating Jie,
it is better to conceal one's intelligence and return to cultivating the Way.
Be pure and still, without action,
and Heaven will give you the right time;
be honest and frugal, upholding your integrity,
and the earth will produce wealth for you;
conduct yourself with simplicity and be known for your virtue,
and the sages will make plans for you.
Therefore, the humble are those to whom all things return,
and the empty are those whom the world leaves behind.
Now, when the ruler listens to affairs of state,
he is clear and discerning, not obscured,
with an empty mind and weakened will.
Therefore, the multitude of ministers converge and advance together.
Whether foolish or wise, virtuous or unworthy,
none fail to exert their abilities to the utmost.
Only then can he begin to set forth the rites
and establish them as the foundation.
This is like riding the strength of the masses as a carriage,
and employing the wisdom of the masses as horses.
Even though (the situation) is secluded wilds and dangerous paths,
then there is no way to be misled.
The ruler of men dwells deeply in a hidden place
to avoid dryness and dampness,
doors upon doors in multiple layers
to guard against treachery and thieves;
inside, he does not know the conditions of the villages;
outside, he does not know the shapes of the mountains and marshes.
Beyond the curtains and screens,
his eyes cannot see.
Beyond ten li, his ears cannot hear beyond a hundred paces.
Yet there is nothing in the world
that he does not understand,
because that which irrigates (him) is great,
and those who advise (him) are numerous.
Therefore, without going out the door, he knows the world;
without looking out the window, he knows the Way of Heaven.
By harnessing the wisdom of the multitude,
then the world is not enough to possess.
If he relies solely on his own mind,
then he cannot even protect himself alone.
Therefore, the ruler covers (the people) with virtue,
does not act on his own intelligence,
but relies on what benefits the myriad people.
When he raises his heel, the world obtains benefit;
therefore, dwelling above the hundred surnames,
he is not burdensome;
stepping before the people
without harming them;
lifting them up without being haughty;
pushing them forward without being tiresome.
The way of the ruler is circular,
revolving without end,
transforming and nurturing like a spirit,
empty and following along,
always behind and never ahead.
The way of the minister is square,
discussing what is right and abiding in the proper place,
taking the lead in doing things,
clearly guarding one's duties,
in order to establish success.
Therefore, if the ruler and minister have different paths, there is order;
if they have the same path, there is chaos.
Each obtaining what is appropriate for them,
residing in the proper place,
then superiors and inferiors have a means to employ each other.
Now, the way the ruler listens to governance is
with an empty heart and a subdued will,
clear and bright without being clouded.
Therefore, the assembled ministers converge and advance together,
whether foolish or wise, virtuous or unworthy,
none fail to exhaust their abilities.
Then the ruler gains the means to control the ministers,
and the ministers gain the means to serve the ruler.
The way to govern a state is clear.
King Wen was wise and loved to ask questions,
therefore he was sage.
King Wu was brave and loved to ask questions,
therefore he was victorious.
To harness the wisdom of the many,
there is nothing one cannot undertake;
to employ the strength of the many,
there is nothing one cannot overcome.
The weight of a thousand jun,
Wu Huo could not lift;
but when the many unite as one,
then a hundred men have strength to spare.
Therefore, relying on the strength of one man,
then Wu Huo is not worth depending on;
but harnessing the control of the many,
then the whole world is not enough to possess.
Yu dredged the Yangzi and cleared the Yellow River,
to bring benefit to the world,
yet he could not make water flow west.
Ji cleared land and cultivated grass,
to encourage the people to labor in agriculture,
yet he could not make grain grow in winter.
Was it that their efforts were insufficient?
It was that the natural course could not be changed.
To attempt what cannot be done,
and not follow the principles of reason,
Even divine sages cannot achieve success if they go against this,
how much less so the rulers of the present age!
If the load is heavy and the horse is weak,
even Zhao Fu (a famous charioteer) cannot travel far.
If the cart is light and the horse is good,
even an ordinary craftsman can make it travel swiftly.
Therefore, when a sage undertakes something,
how can he violate the principles of reason,
defy the nature of things,
and bend the crooked into the straight,
and twist the bent into the stretched?
He never fails to use things according to their inherent properties.
Therefore, what is raised by accumulated strength
will be invariably victorious;
and what is accomplished by the collective wisdom
will be invariably successful.
A deaf person can be made to chew on sinew,
but cannot be made to hear;
a mute person can be made to guard a pen,
but cannot be made to communicate.
The physical form is limited in some respects,
and capable in others.
Therefore, let each form be placed in a suitable position,
and let each ability be assigned to a suitable task.
If one's strength exceeds one's responsibility,
then those who delegate will not feel burdened;
if one's ability matches one's task,
then those who perform the task will not find it difficult.
Whether small or large, long or short,
each obtains what is appropriate for it,
then the whole world will be in order,
and there will be nothing to surpass each other.
The sage employs all these talents inclusively,
therefore there is no discarding of talent.
A ruler values uprightness and esteems loyalty.
If loyalty and uprightness are in high positions,
and uprightness governs affairs,
then slander, sycophancy, treachery, and wickedness will have no way to advance.
It is like squares and circles not fitting together,
and curves and straight lines not intermixing.
The reason why birds and beasts do not flock together
is that their kinds are different;
the reason why tigers and deer do not roam together
is that their strengths are unequal.
Therefore, if a sage obtains his ambition and is in a high position,
and slanderers, sycophants, traitors, and the wicked desire to offend the ruler,
it is like a sparrow seeing a hawk
or a mouse encountering a wildcat,
and surely there will be no remaining life.
Therefore, the appointments of a ruler
cannot but be made with caution.
If those appointed are the right people,
then the state will be well-governed,
superiors and inferiors will be harmonious,
the ministers will be close,
and the people will be attached.
If those appointed are not the right people,
then the state will be in danger,
superiors and inferiors will be discordant,
the ministers will be resentful,
and the people will be in chaos.
Therefore, one incorrect action
will cause lifelong harm.
The way to success and failure,
the power and importance of it rest with the ruler.
Therefore, if the plumb line is correct at the top,
the wood will be straight at the bottom.
It is not that something special happens,
it is simply that [the wood] is straight because of the standard it follows.
Therefore, if the ruler is truly upright,
then honest officials will be appointed to office,
and wicked people will hide themselves.
If the ruler is not upright,
then wicked people will achieve their ambitions,
and loyal officials will remain hidden.
Why is it that people do not pick up jade and stones but instead pick up melons and gourds?
Because there is nothing to be gained from jade and stones, and they are not to be trifled with.
If the ruler holds to correctness and maintains impartiality,
as if following the plumb line for height,
then those officials who come with evil intentions
will be like throwing an egg at a stone,
or throwing fire into water.
Therefore, King Ling favored slender waists,
and the people starved themselves to death;
the King of Yue favored bravery,
and the people all dwelt in danger and contended for death.
Judging from this,
the handle of power and influence,
Those who speak of affairs must be investigated according to the law,
and those who take action must be governed by officials.
The ruler grasps their titles
to demand their actual accomplishments.
The ministers uphold their duties
to demonstrate their merits.
Words must not exceed their reality,
actions must not transgress the law.
All the ministers converge,
none dare monopolize the ruler.
If an affair is not within the laws
but can benefit the country and aid governance,
one must comprehensively examine it through the yin aspect of the Five Elements
to observe its ultimate end,
and employ widespread listening
to observe its transformations.
Not biased towards one side,
not favoring one affair,
therefore, being neutral and impartial, radiating light throughout the country.
All the ministers are fair and just,
none dare engage in wickedness.
All officials report on their duties,
striving to achieve public achievements.
The ruler is insightful and clear above,
the officials encourage effort below.
Treacherous and evil disappear,
public achievements advance daily.
Therefore, the brave exhaust their efforts in the army.
The state of disorder is not like this.
There, those who are praised by the multitude
are rewarded without merit,
and those who guard their posts
are punished without crime.
The ruler is benighted and unseeing,
the assembled officials are partisan and disloyal,
those who engage in discourse delight in argument,
and those who cultivate themselves vie to outdo each other.
When the ruler issues an order,
they find fault with it in order to disagree;
what the laws forbid,
they wickedly violate.
Those who consider themselves wise strive for cunning and deceit,
those who consider themselves brave strive for fighting and contention,
great ministers monopolize power,
lower officials hold onto influence,
cliques and factions conspire and compare,
in order to manipulate their superiors.
Though the state may appear to exist,
the ancients would say it is already lost.
Furthermore, those who do not manage official duties, do not wear armor and carry weapons,
do not cultivate the southern fields, but have a reputation for sagacity and wisdom,
are not fit to instruct the state.
*Qiji* and *Luyi*
are the fastest horses in the world.
If you drive them and they don't move forward,
if you pull them and they don't stop,
Even a fool would not add (anything) to it.
Now, the mechanism of order and chaos,
its tracks and traces can be seen.
But the lords of the world are unable to perceive it.
This is why the path to order is blocked.
Power and authority are
the carriages and vehicles of the ruler;
rank and emolument are
the reins and bits of the ministers.
Therefore, the ruler occupies the crucial point of power and authority,
and holds the handle of rank and emolument,
assesses the degree of urgency,
and appropriately regulates the measure of taking and giving.
Because of this, the world exerts its strength without fatigue.
Now, the relationship between ministers and rulers
is not based on the deep affection of father and son, nor the kinship of flesh and blood,
yet they exhaust their strength and die for him,
not hesitating to sacrifice their bodies. Why is this?
It is the power of circumstances that makes them do so.
In the past, Yu Rang
was a minister of Zhonghang Wenzi.
Zhi Bo attacked the Zhonghang clan,
annexed its territory.
Yu Rang abandoned his lord and became a minister of Zhi Bo.
Zhi Bo fought with Zhao Xiangzi below Jinyang,
and was killed and his body mutilated,
The state was divided into three.
Yu Rang desired to avenge Zhao Xiangzi.
He lacquered his body to look like a leper,
swallowed charcoal to change his voice,
knocked out his teeth and altered his appearance.
Now, concerning a single person's loyalty
to two different lords,
some turn their backs and leave,
while others desire to sacrifice themselves for the lord.
Is it that the direction of their attachment or detachment depends on the differing powers of influence?
No, it is the kindness and favor shown to them that causes this.
Zhou possessed all under Heaven,
held court with the feudal lords,
wherever human footprints reached,
wherever boats and oars could travel,
none failed to submit.
Yet King Wu, with three thousand armored soldiers,
captured him at Muye.
Was it that the Zhou people died for their principles while the Yin people betrayed?
No, it was that their lord's virtuous conduct was substantial and his commands were effective.
When the wind is strong, waves rise;
when the tree is luxuriant, birds gather—
these are instances of mutual generation.
Therefore, when a subject cannot obtain what he desires from his lord,
the lord also cannot obtain what he seeks from his subject.
The bestowals between lord and subject
are situations of mutual reciprocity.
Therefore, a subject exerts his utmost strength and dies for his principles to give to his lord,
He calculates to bestow rank in order to trade with his subjects.
Therefore, the ruler cannot reward ministers who have no merit,
and the ministers also cannot die for a ruler who has no virtue.
If the ruler's virtue does not flow down to the people,
and yet he wishes to employ them,
it is like whipping the legs of a horse.
This is like seeking ripe crops without waiting for rain,
certainly a matter of impossibility.
The way of being a ruler
is to cultivate oneself in stillness,
and to lead subordinates through frugality and restraint.
When there is stillness, then subordinates will not be disturbed;
when there is frugality, then the people will not resent.
If subordinates are disturbed, then the government is chaotic;
if the people resent, then virtue is thin.
If the government is chaotic, then the worthy will not offer counsel;
if virtue is thin, then the brave will not die for him.
Therefore, if a ruler is fond of fierce birds and savage beasts,
rare and strange objects,
cunning, restlessness, comfort and idleness,
and does not cherish the strength of the people,
gallops about in hunting,
enters and exits without fixed times,
then the hundred officials will be in chaotic business,
affairs will be laborious and wealth exhausted,
the myriad people will be anxious and bitter,
and their livelihoods will not be cultivated.
If the ruler of men favors high terraces and deep ponds,
carving and elaborate ornamentation,
elaborate embroidered designs,
fine linen and elaborate silk embroidery,
precious jewels and jade,
then taxation will be without limit,
and the strength of the myriad people will be exhausted.
When Yao possessed the world,
it was not out of greed for the wealth of the myriad people
and to secure the position of the ruler,
but because he thought that the people were toiling,
the strong bullying the weak,
and the many oppressing the few.
Therefore, Yao personally practiced frugality,
and demonstrated the benevolence of mutual love,
in order to harmonize and pacify them.
Therefore, he did not trim his thatched roof,
did not carve the rafters of his house,
did not paint the great roads,
did not trim the rush mats,
did not season the thick soup,
and did not polish the millet.
He went on tours of inspection to spread his teachings,
worked diligently for the world,
and traveled around the Five Peaks.
Was it that his own sustenance was not sufficient to bring him joy?
He thought that it was for the good of the state.
When he grew old and his ambitions diminished,
To yield the whole empire and pass it on to Shun
is like walking backwards and casting off one's sandals.
But in an age of decline, it is not so.
To possess the wealth of the empire in a single day,
and occupy the position of the ruler,
then one exhausts the strength of the people
to gratify the desires of the ears and eyes.
One's will is focused solely on palaces, terraces, and pavilions,
ponds, gardens, and parks,
fierce beasts, bears, and pandas,
trinkets, curiosities, and rarities.
Therefore, the poor people do not have even dregs and husks to eat,
while tigers, wolves, bears, and pandas are sated with grain-fed meat;
the common people have coarse, tattered clothing,
while the palaces are adorned with brocade and embroidery.
The ruler is preoccupied with these useless pursuits,
while the black-haired people grow gaunt and weary throughout the land.
Therefore, he causes the empire to be uneasy in its nature.
The abode of the ruler
is like the brightness of the sun and moon;
it is what the whole world looks at sideways and watches closely,
listens to intently,
and stretches their necks and raises their heels to behold.
Therefore, without indifference, there is no way to illuminate virtue;
without tranquility, there is no way to achieve far-reaching influence;
without generosity, there is no way to encompass and cover;
without benevolence, there is no way to cherish the masses;
Without fairness and impartiality, there is no way to judge and decide.
Therefore, when a wise ruler employs people,
it is like a skilled craftsman shaping wood.
The large pieces are used for boats, rafts, pillars, and beams,
the small pieces are used for tenons and mortises,
the long pieces are used for eaves and rafters,
the short pieces are used for dwarf columns, brackets, and bases.
Regardless of size or length,
each gets what is suitable for it.
Circles and squares,
each have their proper use.
Different shapes and different materials,
none are unusable.
Of all things in the world,
nothing is more harmful than the poison of the Hsi tribe,
yet a good doctor carries it in a bag and stores it,
because it has its uses.
Therefore, even the wood of the forest and thickets
is not to be discarded,
how much more so with people!
Now, those whom the court does not promote,
and whom the villages do not praise,
it is not that those people are unworthy,
but that the office assigned to them is not suitable for their abilities.
When deer go up the mountain,
even the large elk cannot climb,
but when they come down,
Even a shepherd boy can pursue it,
talents have their strengths and weaknesses.
Therefore, those with grand strategies
cannot be expected to have quick skills,
those with petty intelligence
cannot be entrusted with great tasks.
People have their talents,
things have their shapes,
some are overloaded with a single task,
or some are still light even with a hundred tasks.
Therefore, those who are meticulous in small calculations
will inevitably neglect the grand order of the universe;
those who do not miss the selection of small items
may err in the undertaking of great affairs.
It is like a wildcat cannot be made to wrestle an ox,
a tiger cannot be made to catch mice.
Now, people's talents,
some wish to pacify the nine provinces,
follow those beyond the square (outside the norm),
preserve endangered states,
continue extinguished lineages,
their ambition lies in straightening crooked paths and correcting wrongs,
resolving tangled affairs and managing complexities,
yet they are blamed for the etiquette of the boudoir,
in the secluded inner chambers.
Or, those with petty cleverness,
flattering and pleasing with insincere words,
following the customs of the local village,
To humble oneself and rely on the eyes and ears of the masses,
and yet entrust them with the power of the empire,
the hinge of order and chaos;
this is like using an axe to trim hair,
or using a knife to fell a tree,
both losing their appropriateness.
A ruler,
uses the eyes of the empire to see,
uses the ears of the empire to hear,
uses the wisdom of the empire to deliberate,
uses the strength of the empire to act.
Therefore, commands can reach the lowest levels,
and the feelings of the subjects can be heard above,
all officials communicate smoothly,
all ministers converge,
joy is not expressed through rewards,
anger is not expressed through punishment.
Therefore, authority is established and not abandoned,
intelligence shines brightly and is not obscured,
laws are clear and not harsh,
ears and eyes are perceptive and not darkened,
the true state of good and bad
is presented daily before him without obstruction.
Therefore, the wise exhaust their wisdom,
the unworthy exhaust their strength,
virtue and beneficence cover all without partiality,
all ministers are encouraged in their duties and are not lazy,
those nearby are secure in their nature,
those far away cherish his virtue.
The reason for this?
Is that he has mastered the way of using people,
and does not rely on his own talents.
Therefore, those who borrow carriages and horses,
without tiring his feet, can reach a thousand *li*;
one who rides in boats and oars,
though unable to swim, can cross rivers and seas.
It is the nature of rulers
that none do not desire to gather the wisdom of the whole world
and exhaust the strength of all the people,
but those ministers who express their will and offer their loyalty
rarely escape being burdened.
If what is said is right,
even if it comes from a commoner gathering firewood,
it should not be discarded.
If what is said is wrong,
even if it comes from a high minister or the ruler,
brandishing a writing tablet in the ancestral hall,
it is not necessarily usable.
Where right and wrong lie
cannot be determined by noble or humble, high or low status.
This is how an enlightened ruler listens to his ministers;
if their plans are usable,
he is not ashamed of their positions;
if their words are actionable,
He does not fault their arguments.
A benighted ruler is not like this;
those whom he loves and is accustomed to, those whom he keeps close,
even if they are wicked, crooked, and not upright,
he cannot see it;
those who are distant, removed, lowly, and humble,
even if they exhaust their strength and offer their utmost loyalty,
he cannot know it.
Those who speak, he corners them with words;
those who remonstrate, he punishes them with crimes.
To want to illuminate the land within the seas
and preserve the myriad regions with such behavior,
is like plugging one's ears and listening for clear and turbid sounds,
or covering one's eyes and trying to distinguish blue and yellow.
How far removed from sagacity would such a person be!
Law is
the measure of all under Heaven
and the plumb line of the ruler.
To establish law
is to regulate what is lawful and unlawful;
to establish rewards
is to reward those who deserve reward.
Once the law is established,
those who meet the standard are rewarded,
those who fall short of the line are punished.
The noble are not let off lightly from their punishment,
and the lowly are not subjected to heavier punishments.
Even if the lawbreaker is virtuous, he must be punished;
if the one whose behavior is middling is not worthy, he must still be without guilt.
Therefore, the public way opens, and the private way closes.
In ancient times, the establishment of officials
was for the purpose of restraining the people,
so that they could not act according to their own desires.
The establishment of the ruler was for the purpose of controlling the officials,
so that they would not act independently.
Laws, records, rites, and righteousness
were for the purpose of restraining the ruler,
so that he would not make arbitrary decisions.
If no one is allowed to act according to their own desires,
then the Way prevails.
When the Way prevails, principle is achieved,
therefore, one returns to non-action.
Non-action
does not mean being stagnant and unmoving,
but rather means that nothing originates from oneself.
Now, the inch is born from the *biao* (gnomon);
the *biao* is born from the shape;
the shape is born from the shadow;
the shadow is born from the sun.
This is the origin of measurement.
Music is born from sound;
sound is born from pitch-pipes;
pitch-pipes are born from wind;
this is the source of sound.
Law arises from righteousness,
righteousness arises from what is suitable for the multitude,
what is suitable for the multitude accords with the hearts of the people—
this is the key to governance.
Therefore, one who is versed in the root
will not be confused by the branches,
one who perceives the essentials
will not be perplexed by the details.
Law is not something that falls from heaven,
nor is it something that grows from the earth;
it originates among men
and in turn is used to rectify themselves.
Therefore, having something oneself, one does not condemn it in others;
lacking something oneself, one does not demand it of others;
what is established for those below
is not abolished by those above;
what is prohibited to the people
is not practiced by oneself.
What is meant by “a state perishes”
is not that it lacks a ruler,
but that it lacks law.
“Changing the law”
is not that there is no law,
but that there is law but it is not used,
which is the same as having no law.
Therefore, when the ruler establishes laws,
he should first use himself as a model and standard,
so that his orders will be carried out throughout the land.
Confucius said:
"If his person is upright,
he will be followed even without giving orders.
If his person is not upright,
even if he gives orders, they will not be followed."
Therefore, if prohibitions are effective for oneself,
then orders will be carried out among the people.
The governance of a sage ruler
is like Zaofu's charioteering.
He aligns and harmonizes at the reins and bit,
and adjusts speed to the harmony of his lips and mouth.
He sets the standard in his heart and mind,
and firmly holds the guidance between his hands.
His inner intentions are aligned,
and outwardly match the will of the horses.
Therefore, he can advance and retreat on a straight line,
and turn and curve within the compass.
He chooses the right path to reach far,
and has strength to spare.
Truly, he has mastered the art.
Therefore, authority and power
are the ruler's carriage;
great ministers
are the ruler's team of four horses.
If the body is separated from the carriage's stability,
and the hand loses the horses' hearts,
and yet can remain safe,
This has never happened, either in ancient or modern times.
Therefore, if the carriage and horses are not in harmony,
even Wang Liang cannot use them to find the road;
if the ruler and ministers are not in harmony,
even Tang and Yu cannot use them to govern.
If one clings to techniques and attempts to control,
then the wisdom of Guan Zhong and Yan Ying will be exhausted;
if one clearly defines duties and shows them,
then the treachery of Zhi and Qiao will cease.
Now, if one holds onto a tree trunk and peers into the bottom of a well,
even with sharp vision, one cannot see clearly;
but if one borrows the brightness of a mirror to illuminate it,
then even the smallest detail can be observed.
Therefore, the ears and eyes of an enlightened ruler are not strained,
their spirit is not exhausted;
when things arrive, they observe their changes,
when affairs come, they respond to their transformations,
those nearby are not in chaos,
and even those far away are governed well.
Therefore, they do not rely on accidental methods,
but follow the path of certainty,
so that every action is without a failed plan.
Now, consider a charioteer:
if the horses' bodies are attuned to the chariot,
and the charioteer's heart is in harmony with the horses,
then they can traverse dangers and reach distant places,
Moving forward or retreating, traveling around,
nothing is not as one wishes.
Even though there are fine steeds like the Qi Ji or Lu Er,
if a lowly servant drives them,
then the horses will instead act willfully,
and the person will be unable to control them.
Therefore, a ruler does not value being right according to his own judgment,
but values being unable to do wrong.
Therefore, it is said:
"Do not allow things to be desirable,
do not say you will not seek them.
Do not allow things to be seized,
do not say you will not contend for them."
If this is the case,
then talent will be released, and impartial justice will be practiced.
Those who covet will stop at the limit,
and those who are insufficient will be employed appropriately,
therefore the whole world can be unified.
Now, if one abandons official duties and listens to improper praise and blame,
discards public merit and employs partisan cliques,
then extraordinary talents will be frivolous and exceed their rank,
and those who uphold their offices will be obstructed and unable to advance.
If this is the case,
then the customs of the people will be disordered in the state,
and meritorious officials will contend in the court.
Therefore, laws and measures
are what the ruler uses to control his subordinates.
To release them (the ministers) and not employ them,
is like riding a horse without reins or a bit.
The assembled ministers and common people
will instead manipulate their superiors.
Therefore, possessing method (術) enables one to control others;
lacking method results in being controlled by others.
A fish that can swallow a boat,
tossed about and losing its water,
is then controlled by ants.
It's separated from its dwelling.
An ape that loses its tree is captured by foxes and wildcats.
It is not its proper place.
If the ruler abandons what he should guard and contends with his subordinates over affairs,
then officials will maintain their positions by doing nothing,
and those who guard their posts will seek favor with the ruler by following his lead.
Thus, subordinates conceal their wisdom and do not use it,
and instead transfer the responsibility for affairs back to their superiors.
When it comes to labor, the noble and wealthy;
when it comes to investigation, those experienced in affairs;
when it comes to respect, the arrogant and indulgent;
their power does not extend to the ruler.
If the ruler does not entrust abilities and likes to do things himself,
then his wisdom will be exhausted daily, and he will bear the responsibility alone.
His reckoning is exhausted by his subordinates,
then he cannot extend his principles.
His conduct is degraded in the state,
then he cannot exclusively control.
If wisdom is insufficient for governing,
and authority is insufficient for carrying out punishments,
then there is no way to interact with those below.
If joy and anger are manifested in the heart,
and desires are visible externally,
then those who hold office will deviate from righteousness and flatter their superiors,
and officials will bend the law and follow the wind.
Rewards will not match merit,
and punishments will not correspond to crimes.
Those above and below will be disaffected,
and the ruler and ministers will resent each other.
Therefore, if those in power flatter the ruler, and there is a fault
then there is no way to hold them accountable.
If there is crime and it is not punished,
then all the officials will be in chaos,
and wisdom will be unable to resolve it;
slander and praise will arise,
and clarity will be unable to illuminate it.
If one does not correct the root but instead focuses on self-cultivation,
then the ruler will become increasingly burdened,
and the ministers will become increasingly idle.
This is like substituting for the cook in butchering the sacrificial animal,
and being the master craftsman for the chiseling.
Competing in running with a horse,
the sinews will snap and one will not be able to catch up;
boarding a carriage and holding the reins,
then the horse submits under the yoke.
Therefore, with Bole appraising it,
Wang Liang drove it,
and an enlightened ruler rode it.
Without the labor of driving or assisting, one could travel a thousand *li*,
relying on human resources as wings.
Therefore, the ruler of men
is without action but has something to guard,
and has standards but no personal preferences.
If there is action, slander arises;
if there are preferences, flattery emerges.
In the past, Duke Huan of Qi loved flavors,
and Yi Ya cooked his eldest son and used him as bait.
The Lord of Yu loved treasures,
and Duke Xian of Jin used jade and horses to lure him.
The King of the Hu loved music,
and Duke Mu of Qin used female musicians to seduce him.
All these were cases of being controlled by others through the lure of profit.
Therefore, what is well-established cannot be uprooted,
meaning that the establishment is formless.
Fire is hot, but water extinguishes it;
metal is hard, but fire melts it;
wood is strong, but an axe fells it;
water flows, but earth stops it.
Only the Creator
can overcome all things.
Therefore, preventing desires from escaping within is called "closing."
Preventing external evils from entering is called "shutting."
With the inner being closed and the outer being shut,
Is there anything that cannot be regulated?
With the outer gate closed and the inner bolt fastened,
is there anything that cannot be accomplished?
Only after not using can one use;
only after not doing can one do.
If the spirit and mind are exhausted, they will overflow;
if the ears and eyes are indulged, they will be depleted.
Therefore, the enlightened ruler
eliminates thoughts and dispels intentions,
maintaining a state of purity and emptiness to await (events).
He does not substitute his own words,
nor does he seize affairs (from his ministers).
He follows names to demand reality,
and officials are allowed to manage their own affairs. He entrusts (tasks) without instructing,
and holds accountable without teaching.
He takes "not knowing" as the Dao,
and regards "what to do?" as a treasure.
If this is so,
then the affairs of the hundred officials
will each have their own proper boundaries.
Grasping the handle of power and authority,
transforming the people becomes easy.
The Duke of Wei was humbled by Zilu,
because the authority (of Zilu) was weighty.
Duke Jing and Duke Huan were ministers to Guan Zhong and Yan Ying,
because their positions were respected.
Cowardice overcomes courage, and foolishness controls wisdom;
That which relies on strategic advantage achieves victory.
Therefore, a branch cannot be larger than the trunk,
and the extremities cannot be stronger than the root.
This speaks of how the light and heavy, small and
large, mutually control each other.
It is like the five fingers belonging to the arm;
grasping, pulling, seizing, and being agile
all proceed as desired.
This speaks of how the small belongs to the large.
Therefore, he who obtains the advantage of strategic position,
holds something very small,
and shoulders something very large;
guards something very narrow,
and controls something very broad.
Therefore, a tree ten spans around
can support a house weighing thousands of catties;
a five-inch key
controls opening and closing.
Is it truly because their material size is sufficient to bear the responsibility?
It is because they occupy a vital position.
Confucius and
Mozi
cultivated the methods of the former sages,
comprehended the discourses of the Six Arts,
spoke their words,
acted out their ambitions,
admired righteousness and followed its influence,
yet those who wore their clothes and served them were no more than several tens of people.
If they were placed in the position of the Son of Heaven,
then the whole world would become followers of Confucianism and Mohism.
When King Zhuang of Chu lamented the death of Wen Wuwei in Song,
he raised his sleeves and stood up,
his robes and caps connecting on the road,
and then formed an army under the city of Song,
because his power was great.
King Wen of Chu liked to wear a loose hat,
and the state of Chu imitated him;
King Wuling of Zhao wore a shell belt and pheasant feathers to court,
and the state of Zhao transformed itself accordingly.
If they were commoners in plain clothes,
even if they wore a loose hat,
wore a shell belt, and pheasant feathers to court,
they would not avoid being laughed at.
Among the people, those who love goodness and delight in righteousness,
and spontaneously conform to laws and measures without the need for prohibitions and executions,
are one in ten thousand.
If an order is issued that must be carried out,
those who follow it will benefit,
and those who oppose it will suffer disaster,
and before the shadow of the sun has moved,
the whole world will be bound by the rules.
Therefore, if you hold the blade of a sword,
even Bei Gongzi and Sima Kuai Kui cannot be made to face the enemy;
if you grasp its handle,
Grasp the end of the matter,
and even a mediocre person can use it to achieve victory.
Now, suppose we had Wu Huo or Jie Fan
pulling on the tail of an ox from behind.
If the tail breaks and the ox doesn't follow,
it's resistance.
But if you pierce the ox's nose with a mulberry twig
and use it to lead,
then even a five-foot-tall child
can lead it around the world,
because it's compliance.
That a seven-foot rudder
can control the movement of a ship left and right
is because it relies on the water as its resource.
That the emperor's commands
are carried out and prohibitions are enforced
is because he relies on the power of the masses.
Preventing what harms the people
and opening up what benefits the people
is how authority is exercised,
like releasing a dam or breaching a pond.
Therefore, going downstream
is easy to reach the destination,
and running with the wind
is easy to go far.
When Duke Huan established his government,
he removed beasts that eat meat,
Birds that eat grain
are caught in snares and nets.
After three actions, the people rejoiced.
Zhou killed Prince Bigan, and his flesh and blood became resentful;
he cut off the legs of those crossing the river in the morning, and all the people rebelled.
After two actions, he lost the empire.
Therefore, righteousness
is not about being able to benefit all the people in the world;
benefitting one person, and the world follows like the wind.
Tyranny
is not about being able to harm all the people within the seas;
harming one person, and the world becomes estranged and rebellious.
Therefore, Duke Huan, after three actions, united the feudal lords nine times.
Zhou, after two actions, could not even remain a commoner.
Therefore, actions cannot be taken without careful consideration.
When a ruler levies taxes from the people,
he must first calculate the annual harvest,
measure the people's accumulated wealth,
and know the numbers of abundance and scarcity, surplus and deficiency,
and then take carts, clothing, food, and drink to satisfy his desires.
High platforms and storied pavilions,
connected houses and linked chambers,
are not unbeautiful,
but if the people have no dug-out dwellings or narrow huts
in which to find shelter,
then an enlightened ruler will not enjoy them.
Rich, thick, sweet, and crisp foods
are not unappetizing,
However, if the people have not even dregs and husks, beans and grain
to put in their mouths,
then the enlightened ruler does not relish fine food.
A simple bed and rush mat
are not uncomfortable,
yet if the people are stationed on the border,
facing danger and hardship,
and die exposed as corpses,
then the enlightened ruler does not feel at peace.
Therefore, the rulers of men in ancient times,
were deeply concerned for the people;
if the country had hungry people,
they would not eat rich food;
if the people were cold,
they would not wear fur coats in winter.
Only when the year was good and the people prosperous,
would they then hang bells and drums,
display shields and axes,
and ruler and ministers, superiors and inferiors,
would rejoice together in harmony,
and the country would have no grieving people.
Therefore, in ancient times, bronze bells, stone chimes, wind instruments, and stringed instruments
were used to express joy;
armor, weapons, axes, and halberds
were used to display anger;
goblets, platters, and sacrificial vessels,
the rituals of toasting and responding,
Therefore, acting out joy is a matter of imitation;
wearing mourning clothes and straw sandals,
stamping one's feet, leaping, and crying,
are ways to express sorrow.
All these things have substance within, and become images outwardly.
But when it comes to tyrannical rulers,
they take from the people without considering their strength,
and demand from those below without measuring their stores.
Men and women are unable to engage in the work of plowing and weaving
to supply the demands of those above.
Labor is diligent, resources are exhausted,
and ruler and subject hate each other.
Therefore, the people reach the point of parched lips and boiling livers,
living for the present with no reserves for the future.
And then they start striking large bells,
beating sounding drums,
blowing pipes and reed organs,
and playing zithers and lutes.
This is like wearing armor and entering the ancestral temple,
or putting on fine silk and following the army,
losing the source from which joy arises.
Now, as for the livelihood of the people,
one man holding a plow,
cultivating no more than ten acres,
the yield of an average field,
the harvest at the end of the year,
is no more than four bushels per acre.
Wives and children are old and weak,
looking up to him for food.
At times there are worries of excessive rain and drought disasters,
and there are ways to provide for the levies of the superiors and the expenses of chariots, horses, soldiers, and weapons.
Viewing it from this perspective,
then the lives of the people are distressing!
Considering the greatness of Heaven and Earth,
calculate that after three years of cultivation, there is a surplus of one year's food;
generally, after nine years there is a store of three years;
after eighteen years there is an accumulation of six years;
after twenty-seven years there is a reserve of nine years.
Even with the calamities of excessive rain and drought disasters,
the people will not be mired in poverty and displacement.
Therefore, a state without a store of nine years is
called insufficient;
without an accumulation of six years is
called distressing and urgent;
without a store of three years is
called impoverished.
Therefore, if there are benevolent rulers and enlightened lords,
their exactions from below are measured,
and their self-cultivation is moderate,
then they can receive support from Heaven and Earth,
and will not be separated from the worry of hunger and cold.
If they obtain greedy lords and tyrannical rulers,
who harass those below them,
encroach upon and plunder their people,
to satisfy endless desires,
then the common people will have no way to receive the harmony of Heaven and tread on the virtue of Earth.
Food is the foundation of the people.
The people are the foundation of the state.
The state is the foundation of the ruler.
Therefore, he who rules the people
above relies on the timing of Heaven,
below exhausts the resources of Earth,
and in the middle employs the strength of the people.
Thus, all living things thrive and grow,
and the five grains flourish.
Teach the people to raise the six domestic animals,
to plant trees in season,
to diligently cultivate the fields,
to increase the planting of mulberry and hemp,
and to make the most of fertile or barren, high or low ground,
each according to its suitability.
On hills and slopes that cannot produce the five grains,
plant bamboo and trees;
in spring, cut down the withered and dead,
in summer, gather fruits and melons,
in autumn, store vegetables and food,
and in winter, cut firewood and fuel,
to provide resources for the people.
Therefore, in life there will be no shortage of supplies,
and in death there will be no uncovered corpses.
Hence, the laws of the former kings were that
hunting should not be done indiscriminately on herds,
Do not take the young of animals.
Do not drain the pond to fish.
Do not burn the forest to hunt.
Before the jackal has sacrificed its catch,
nets and traps must not be set in the fields.
Before the otter has sacrificed its fish,
nets and weirs must not be put in the water.
Before the hawks and falcons have struck,
nets must not be spread in the valleys.
Before the plants and trees have shed their leaves,
axes and hatchets must not enter the mountains and forests.
Before the insects have hibernated,
one must not use fire to till the fields.
Pregnant animals must not be killed.
Unfledged birds' eggs must not be taken.
Fish that are not a foot long must not be caught.
Pigs that are not one year old must not be eaten.
Therefore, the sprouting of plants is like rising steam,
the returning of birds and beasts is like a flowing spring,
the returning of flying birds is like smoke and clouds;
there is a reason for attracting them.
Therefore, in the government of the former kings,
when the clouds of the four seas arrive, they repaired the borders;
when the frogs croaked and the swallows arrived,
they cleared the roads;
when the Yin energy descended and the hundred springs flowed,
they repaired the bridges;
When the [stellar mansion] "Hunzhang" is at the meridian,
then diligently plant grains;
when "Dahuo" is at the meridian,
then plant millet and beans;
when "Xu" is at the meridian,
then plant overwintering wheat;
when "Mao" is at the meridian,
then gather in and store up [the harvest],
and cut firewood.
They informed Heaven above,
and proclaimed it to the people below.
This is how the former kings responded to the seasons and prepared accordingly,
enriched the country and benefited the people,
and in truth, brought those from afar.
Their methods were complete in this.
It was not that they could see it with their eyes and execute it with their feet,
but that they desired to benefit [the people].
If the desire to benefit [the people] is not forgotten in the heart,
then the officials will be naturally well-prepared.
The heart, in relation to the nine orifices and four limbs,
cannot do a single thing,
yet it is the master of all movements, stillness, hearing, and seeing
because it does not forget the desire to benefit [the people].
Therefore, when Yao did good, all good things came;
when Jie did wrong, all wrong things came.
Accumulated good results in accomplished merit;
accumulated wrong results in extreme disaster.
Generally speaking, people's discussions [emphasize that]:
the heart should be small, but the ambition should be great;
the wisdom should be round, but the conduct should be square;
the ability should be diverse, but the affairs should be few.
What is meant by "the heart should be small" is:
to consider worries before they arise,
to prepare for disasters before they occur,
to guard against faults and be cautious about minor matters,
and not to indulge one's desires.
What is meant by "the ambition should be great" is:
to encompass all nations,
to unify different customs,
and to cover all the people
as if they were one family,
so that right and wrong converge like spokes to a hub.
What is meant by "the wisdom should be round" is:
to circulate and revolve continuously,
with no beginning or end,
flowing in all directions,
like a deep spring that never runs dry,
so that all things flourish together,
and all respond accordingly.
What is meant by "the conduct should be square" is:
to stand upright and not yield,
to be pure white and not defiled,
to not change one's principles in poverty,
and not to indulge one's desires in prosperity.
Those capable desire much,
possessing both civil and military virtues,
their actions and stillness are in accordance with the proper manner,
their advancements and abandonments,
all aptly suited,
with nothing jarring or conflicting,
nothing not completely appropriate.
Those whose affairs are few,
grasp the handle and hold the technique,
obtaining the key to respond to the masses,
holding to the concise to govern the vast,
dwelling in stillness and holding the center,
operating from the pivot of power,
unifying myriad things with one,
like matching halves of a tally.
Therefore, one with a small mind
is cautious of the insignificant,
one with great ambition
holds nothing outside their concerns,
one with comprehensive knowledge
has nothing they do not know,
one who acts with principle
has things they will not do,
one who is highly capable
has nothing they cannot govern,
one whose affairs are few
adheres to what is essential.
In ancient times, when the Son of Heaven held court,
he had dukes and ministers offer righteous remonstrance,
erudite scholars recite poetry,
blind admonishers recite admonitions,
commoners transmit words,
historians record his faults,
and stewards remove his food.
Still, he considered this insufficient,
therefore Yao established the drum for bold remonstrance,
Shun erected the tree for slander,
Tang had officials of upright character,
and King Wu established the rattle for caution.
A fault, even as small as a hair,
was already fully guarded against.
Now, the sage toward goodness,
neglects nothing, no matter how small;
and toward faults,
corrects everything, no matter how subtle.
Tang, Yao, Shun, and Wu,
all reigned over the world, facing south in tranquility.
At that time,
they struck the drum to eat,
played the *Yong* to clear the table,
after eating, they sacrificed to the stove,
they did not use shamans for travel,
ghosts and spirits dared not bring misfortune,
mountains and rivers dared not cause calamity.
They could be said to be supremely honored,
Yet, they were apprehensive and trembling,
becoming more cautious day by day.
Judging from this,
then the mind of the sage is small.
The *Book of Poetry* says:
"Oh, this King Wen,
so carefully cautious,
clearly serving God,
thereby receiving much blessing."
Is it not this to which it refers?
When King Wu conquered Yin,
he distributed the grain of Juqiao,
scattered the money of Lutai,
sealed the grave of Bigan,
marked the lane of Shang Rong,
paid respect to the temple of Cheng Tang,
released Ji Zi from prison,
had each return to their homes,
till their fields,
making no changes to the old ways,
only befriending the worthy,
using what was not originally his,
employing those who were not originally his people,
peacefully as if they were his from the beginning.
Judging from this,
then the ambition of the sage is great.
King Wen extensively observed gains and losses,
widely examined rights and wrongs;
The reason Yao and Shun prospered,
and the reason Jie and Zhou perished,
were all displayed in the Mingtang (Bright Hall).
Thus, they possessed broad wisdom and extensive knowledge,
to respond to all situations.
Judging from this,
the wisdom of the sage is complete (round).
King Cheng and King Kang continued the work of King Wen and King Wu,
adhered to the regulations of the Mingtang,
observed the traces of survival and demise,
and witnessed the changes of success and failure.
They did not speak without reason,
and did not act without righteousness.
Their words were not carelessly uttered,
and their actions were not carelessly done.
They chose the good before engaging in affairs.
Judging from this,
the actions of the sage are principled (square).
Confucius's understanding
surpassed that of Chang Hong in wisdom,
and his courage surpassed that of Meng Ben.
His feet could catch hares in the suburbs,
and his strength could open city gates.
His abilities were also numerous.
However, his courage and strength were not renowned,
and his skills were not known.
He focused on practicing filial piety,
to become an uncrowned king.
His actions were also rare.
In the two hundred and forty-two years of the Spring and Autumn period,
fifty-two states perished,
thirty-six rulers were assassinated,
and the good was selected and the bad eliminated
to achieve the way of the true king.
His discussions were also extensive.
However, when surrounded in Kuang,
his countenance did not change,
and his string music did not cease.
Facing a place of death,
braving the dangers of misfortune,
he relied on righteousness and acted according to principle, and his will was not daunted.
His sense of propriety was also clear.
Yet, as Minister of Justice of Lu,
he would certainly decide when hearing cases,
and in composing the "Spring and Autumn Annals,"
he did not speak of ghosts and spirits,
and dared not rely solely on his own opinion.
The wisdom of a sage
is indeed already great,
but what he adheres to is concise,
therefore his actions are always successful.
The wisdom of a fool
is indeed already limited,
but what he deals with is manifold,
therefore his movements are always destined to fail.
Wu Qi and Zhang Yi
To be less wise than Confucius and Mozi,
yet strive to be the ruler of a state with ten thousand chariots,
this is why one would be torn apart by chariots and dismembered.
Indeed, those who use correct principles to educate and transform others
will find it easy and certainly successful;
those who use wicked schemes to deceive the world
will find it difficult and certainly fail.
Whenever one intends to establish practices and set forth purposes in the world,
if one abandons what is easy and certainly leads to success
and instead engages in what is difficult and certainly leads to failure,
it is brought about by foolish delusion.
All these six reversals
must be carefully examined.
To know all things extensively but not to know the Way of humanity
cannot be called wisdom.
To love all living beings extensively but not to love humankind
cannot be called benevolence.
The benevolent love their own kind,
and the wise cannot be deceived.
The benevolent, even in the midst of being cut apart,
show in their expression what they cannot bear.
The wise, even in difficult and complicated matters,
show in their effectiveness that they are not confused.
By inwardly measuring and reflecting on feelings,
what the heart does not desire,
should not be inflicted upon others;
by knowing the near and knowing the far,
Judging others based on oneself
, this is how a wise person acts in accordance with what is fitting for their intelligence.
A little teaching leads to great preservation
, and a little punishment leads to great peace.
Only by extending and implementing compassion
can a wise person make unique judgments.
Therefore, benevolence and wisdom sometimes diverge
and sometimes converge.
Convergence is correctness
, divergence is expediency
, but their underlying principle is the same.
Officials uphold the law
, and the virtuous govern by righteousness.
If there is law without righteousness
, it is merely the work of officials
, and insufficient for governance.
Plowing is a laborious task
, and weaving is a troubling task.
Although plowing and weaving are laborious and troubling
, the people do not abandon them because they know these activities provide clothing and food.
Humans cannot be without clothing and food
, and the means of obtaining clothing and food must begin with plowing and weaving.
This is what all the people see and accept.
Things that are like plowing and weaving
are very laborious at the beginning but ultimately beneficial.
There are many things that can be prepared for
, but a fool prepares for few.
Matters that can be weighed and measured are many,
but the things that the foolish can weigh and measure are few.
This is why the foolish have so many troubles.
Of things that can be prepared for,
the wise prepare for all,
and of things that can be weighed and measured,
they weigh and measure all.
This is why the wise have few troubles.
Therefore, the wise disagree first and then agree later,
while the foolish begin in joy and end in sorrow.
What should be done today for glory,
and what should be done tomorrow for righteousness?
These are easy to say.
What should be done today for righteousness,
and what should be done tomorrow for glory?
These are difficult to know.
Ask a blind musician,
"What is white silk like?"
He will say,
"Bright and lustrous."
Ask,
"What is black like?"
He will say,
"Dark and obscure."
If you take white and black silk and show them to him,
he cannot tell the difference.
People use their eyes to see white and black,
To speak of white and black with the mouth,
a blind master can speak of white and black,
but cannot know white and black.
Therefore, in speaking of white and black, he is the same as others,
but in distinguishing white and black, he is different from others.
To be filial to parents,
and loyal to the ruler,
whether foolish, wise, virtuous, or unworthy,
all know that these are righteous.
But to cause them to act on loyalty and filial piety
and to know where to start
is rare.
In all human thought and consideration,
none do other than first think it possible and then act upon it.
Whether it is right or wrong,
this is how the foolish and wise differ.
Of all human nature,
nothing is more esteemed than benevolence,
nothing is more urgent than wisdom.
Benevolence is the substance,
and wisdom puts it into practice.
These two are the foundation,
and to add to them courage, strength, eloquence, quickness, diligence,
skill, keenness, intelligence, and careful observation
is to add to their benefits.
If one's character is not cultivated,
and their skills are completely equipped,
But without benevolence and wisdom as an outward manifestation and a supporting trunk,
and adding to it numerous fine qualities,
then one only increases the harm.
Therefore, to be without benevolence yet possess courage and decisiveness,
is like a madman wielding a sharp sword;
to be without wisdom yet have eloquence and quick wit,
is like riding a fine steed yet being lost.
Though one may have talent and ability,
if its application is improper,
if its placement is unsuitable,
it will only serve to aid falsehood and disguise wrongdoing.
A multitude of skills and arts
is not as good as having few.
Therefore, those with wild ambitions
must not be lent convenient power;
those with foolish nature
must not be given sharp tools.
Fish find joy in swimming in water,
but if the pond is breached and the water dries up,
they will be eaten by ants and termites.
If there is someone to oversee repairing its dikes and defenses,
patching its gaps and leaks,
then the fish will benefit from it.
A state has a means of survival,
and people have a means of living.
The means by which a state survives
is benevolence and righteousness;
The reason why people live
is to do good.
A country without righteousness,
though large, will surely perish;
a person without good intentions,
though brave, will surely be harmed.
Governing a country
is something that those above cannot force;
being filial to parents,
respectful to elder brothers and sisters-in-law,
and trustworthy to friends
are things that can be done without orders from above.
To abandon what one can do
and demand what one cannot control
is absurd!
A scholar in a humble and secluded position
who desires to rise to prominence
must first examine himself.
There is a way to rise to prominence:
Without a reputation, one cannot rise to prominence.
There is a way to gain a reputation:
Without trustworthiness among friends,
one cannot gain a reputation.
There is a way to be trustworthy among friends:
If serving one's parents is not pleasing,
one cannot be trustworthy among friends.
There is a way to please one's parents:
Without cultivating oneself with sincerity,
unable to serve (one's) parents.
Truly cultivating oneself has a way:
if the heart is not focused and single-minded,
one cannot truly cultivate oneself.
The Way is in the easy, yet seeking it is difficult;
the proof is in the near, yet seeking it is far;
therefore, it cannot be attained.
The incorrect teachings call
the Way supremely high without anything above,
supremely deep without anything below,
level like a plumb line,
straight like a measuring rope,
round like a compass,
square like a set square,
encompassing the universe without inside or outside,
penetrating and covering everything without obstruction.
Therefore, those who embody the Way
neither grieve nor rejoice,
neither are happy nor angry.
When they sit, they have no worries;
when they sleep, they have no dreams.
When things come, they name them;
when affairs come, they respond to them.
The ruler
is the heart of the state.
If the heart is well-governed, all the limbs are at peace;
When the mind is disturbed, all bodily functions are disrupted.
Therefore, when the mind is well-governed,
the limbs and body act as if they are separate entities;
when the state is well-governed,
the ruler and ministers forget each other's existence.
The Yellow Emperor said:
"Vast and obscure,
following the majesty of Heaven,
sharing the same Qi as the origin."
Therefore, one with supreme virtue
speaks with the same aims,
acts with the same purpose,
and has superiors and inferiors of one mind,
with no diverging paths visible,
blocking the way to evil,
and opening the way to goodness,
and the people will then turn towards the right direction.
Therefore, the *Yi* (Book of Changes) says:
"Fellowship with men in the open,
it is advantageous to cross the great stream."
Dao is that which guides things;
De is that which supports the nature;
Ren is the visible proof of accumulated kindness;
Yi is the comparison with people's hearts that conforms to the suitability of the masses.
It is comparable to the human heart and conforms to the suitability of the multitude.
Therefore, when the Way is extinguished, virtue is employed;
when virtue declines, benevolence and righteousness arise.
Therefore, in the highest age, they valued embodying the Way and did not emphasize virtue;
in the middle age, they guarded virtue and did not let it be destroyed;
in the lowest age, they were anxiously concerned, fearing only the loss of benevolence and righteousness.
A superior man cannot live without righteousness;
losing righteousness,
he loses that by which he lives.
A petty man cannot survive without desires;
losing desires,
he loses that by which he survives.
Therefore, the superior man fears losing righteousness,
and the petty man fears losing profit.
Observing what they fear,
one knows they are truly different.
The *Book of Changes* says:
"Chasing a deer without a forester,
one only enters the forest.
A superior man, seeing the situation, would rather give up;
going forward brings regret."
Those who give generously receive a beautiful reward;
those whose resentment is great suffer deep misfortune.
To give sparingly and expect much in return,
to harbor resentment and expect no trouble,
has never happened, in ancient or modern times.
Therefore, the sage observes the path by which one goes
Then one knows the source from which it comes.
The Way of the Sage,
is like setting up a wine vessel at the crossroads?
Those who pass by pour and measure,
in different amounts,
each obtaining what is suitable for them.
Therefore, obtaining one person,
is how one obtains a hundred people.
If one uses what the superiors desire to interact with their subordinates, who would not support them?
Who would not support them?
If one uses what the subordinates desire to serve their superiors,
who would not be pleased?
The *Book of Poetry* says:
"Flatter this one person,
and the princes will carefully cultivate virtue."
Cultivating virtue is a great thing,
one person is a small thing;
if one can be good in small things,
then one can be good in great things.
The gentleman sees an error and forgets the punishment,
therefore he can remonstrate;
sees the worthy and forgets their humble status,
therefore he can yield;
sees insufficiency and forgets poverty,
therefore he can give.
Feelings are tied to the inner heart,
and actions are manifested externally.
Generally, acting with deference to others' feelings
will ensure that even if you err, there will be no resentment.
But if you don't consider their feelings,
even loyal actions will bring about animosity.
Hou Ji broadly benefited the world,
yet he still did not boast of it.
Yu had no wasted efforts
and no hidden wealth,
yet he still regarded himself as deficient.
Being full is like being sunken;
being substantial is like being empty;
these are those who have reached their limit.
Generally, people each praise what they like
and enjoy what pleases them.
The world does not fail to promote those considered worthy,
but some lead to order,
and some to chaos.
This is not from seeking concealment,
but from seeking those who agree with themselves.
If one's own self is not necessarily worthy,
and one seeks those who agree with oneself,
and desires to obtain worthy people,
it is unlikely to happen!
To have Yao evaluate Shun
is acceptable;
to have Jie evaluate Yao
is like using a sheng (a small measuring container) to measure a shi (a larger unit of volume).
Now, if one speaks of a fox-cat,
then surely one will not know what a fox is,
nor will one know what a cat is.
It is not merely that one has never seen a fox,
but one must have also never seen a cat.
